title:
Semigroups of self-similar actions and higher rank Baumslag-Solitar
  semigroups

sections.text:
#### Abstract

In this paper, we initiate the study of higher rank Baumslag-Solitar semigroups and their related $\mathrm{C}^{*}$-algebras. We focus on two rather interesting classes - one is related to products of odometers and the other is related to Furstenberg's $\times p, \times q$ conjecture. For the former class, whose $\mathrm{C}^{*}$-algebras are studied in [38], we here characterize the factoriality of the associated von Neumann algebras and further determine their types; for the latter, we obtain their canonical Cartan subalgebras. In the rank 1 case, we study a more general setting which encompasses (single-vertex) generalized Baumslag-Solitar semigroups. One of our main tools in this paper is from self-similar higher rank graphs and their $\mathrm{C}^{*}$-algebras.

## 1. InTRODUCTION

A self-similar higher rank graph $(G, \Lambda)$ is a pair, which consists of a group $G$ and a higher rank graph $\Lambda$ such that $G$ acts on $\Lambda$ from the left and $\Lambda$ 'acts' on $G$ from the right, where these two actions are compatible in an appropriate way. After [21, 35, 44], self-similar higher rank graphs and their $\mathrm{C}^{*}$-algebras $\mathcal{O}_{G, \Lambda}$ have been systematically studied in [39, 40, 41]. In particular, in [39], when $\Lambda$ is strongly connected, we find a canonical Cartan subalgebra of $\mathcal{O}_{G, \Lambda}$ en route to the study of the KMS states of $\mathcal{O}_{G, \Lambda}$. However, to achieve this, $\Lambda$ is required to be locally faithful. The local faithfulness is a key property to obtain the main results in [39]. Roughly speaking, it guarantees that one could define a periodicity group in a way very similar to higher rank graphs in [15, 16, 26]. It turns out that the local faithfulness condition blocks a lot of interesting examples. This provides our starting point of this paper - to explore non-locally faithful self-similar higher rank graphs and their $\mathrm{C}^{*}$ algebras. During the exploration, we find that a particular non-locally faithful class is closely related to Baumslag-Solitar (BS) semigroups. Due to the higher rank feature, we call such self-similar higher rank graphs higher rank BS semigroups. One extreme case of higher rank BS semigroups is about products of odometers ([38]), while the other extreme case is surprisingly related to Furstenberg's $\times p, \times q$ conjecture.

With semigroups mentioned, there is no surprise that $\Lambda$ is assumed to be single-vertex in this paper. Taking rank 1 (i.e., classical) BS semigroups into consideration, we also consider $G=\mathbb{Z}$ only. For single-vertex higher rank graphs, they have been systematically studied in the literature. To name just a few, see, for instance, [14]-[17], [52, 53]. Those graphs seem very special, but exhibit a lot of interesting properties. Surprisingly, they are also shown to interact intimately with the Yang-Baxter equation ([55]). For BS semigroups, they have

been attracting increasing attention in Operator Algebras recently. See $[7,11,25,36,50]$ and the references therein. Those semigroups provide, on one hand, a class of nice examples for some properties $[11,36,50]$, and on the other hand, some counter-examples for other properties $[7,25]$. Our main purpose in this paper is to mingle single-vertex higher rank graphs and BS semigroups.

The paper is structured as follows. In Section 2, some necessary preliminaries are provided. Although most of them are known, Subsection 2.4 is new, where we introduce a notion of semigroups from self-similar actions. Those semigroups are different from self-similar semigroups/monoids in [3] and the references therein (Remark 2.10). Since the rank 1 case is studied in a more general setting, we focus on this case in Section 3. Even in this case, it includes generalized Baumslag-Solitar (GBS) semigroups, and BS semigroups as well, as examples. We study the periodicity of the associated self-similar graph, and obtain a canonical Cartan subalgebra of its $\mathrm{C}^{*}$-algebra (Propositions 3.22 and 3.23). The simplicity of the $\mathrm{C}^{*}$-algebra is characterized in terms of the relation between the number of edges and the restriction map; and when it is Kirchberg is also described (Theorem 3.20). We turn to higher rank cases in Section 4. We first propose a notion of higher rank BS semigroups (Definition 4.2). We briefly discuss how higher rank BS semigroups are related to Furstenberg's $\times p, \times q$ conjecture in Subsection 4.2. We then focus on two extreme classes. The first extreme class is about products of odometers studied in [38]; but here, we investigate the associated von Neumann algebra: Its factoriality is characterized and its type is also determined (Theorem 4.13). The second extreme class seems trivial at first sight, but turns out to be intriguing. We exhibit a canonical Cartan in this case, which is generally a proper subalgebra of the cycline algebra (Theorem 4.22). We close with computing the spectrum of the fixed point algebra of its gauge action. We hope that we could push Furstenberg's $\times p, \times q$ conjecture further in this vein in our future studies.

Notation and Conventions. Given $1 \leq n \in \mathbb{N}$, let $[n]:=\{0,1, \ldots, n-1\}$. For $1 \leq \mathrm{k} \in \mathbb{N}$, let $\mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}:=(1, \ldots, 1) \in \mathbb{N}^{\mathrm{k}}$.

We use the multi-index notation: For $\mathbf{q}=\left(q_{1}, \ldots, q_{\mathrm{k}}\right)$ and $\mathbf{p}=\left(p_{1}, \ldots, p_{\mathrm{k}}\right)$ in $\mathbb{Z}^{\mathrm{k}}$ with all $p_{i} \neq 0$, let $\mathbf{p}^{\mathbf{q}}:=\prod_{i=1}^{\mathrm{k}} p_{i}^{q_{i}}$.

For convenience, sometimes we also let $\mathbb{Z}=\langle a\rangle$, which is written multiplicatively.
As with most literatures in Operator Algebras, all semigroups in this paper are assumed to be monoids, unless otherwise specified.

# 2. Preliminaries 

2.1. Single-vertex rank k graphs. A countable small category $\Lambda$ is called a rank k graph (or k-graph) if there exists a functor $d: \Lambda \rightarrow \mathbb{N}^{\mathrm{k}}$ satisfying the following unique factorization property: For $\mu \in \Lambda, \mathbf{n}, \mathbf{m} \in \mathbb{N}^{k}$ with $d(\mu)=\mathbf{n}+\mathbf{m}$, there exist unique $\beta \in d^{-1}(\mathbf{n})$ and $\alpha \in d^{-1}(\mathbf{m})$ such that $\mu=\beta \alpha$. A functor $f: \Lambda_{1} \rightarrow \Lambda_{2}$ is called a graph morphism if $d_{2} \circ f=d_{1}$.

Let $\Lambda$ be a k-graph and $\mathbf{n} \in \mathbb{N}^{k}$. Set $\Lambda^{\mathbf{n}}:=d^{-1}(\mathbf{n})$. For $\mu \in \Lambda$, we write $s(\mu)$ and $r(\mu)$ for the source and range of $\mu$, respectively. Then $\Lambda$ is said to be row-finite if $\left|v \Lambda^{\mathbf{n}}\right|<\infty$ for all $v \in \Lambda^{0}$ and $\mathbf{n} \in \mathbb{N}^{\mathrm{k}}$; and source-free if $v \Lambda^{\mathbf{n}} \neq \varnothing$ for all $v \in \Lambda^{0}$ and $\mathbf{n} \in \mathbb{N}^{\mathrm{k}}$. For more information about k-graphs, refer to [33]. In this paper, all k-graphs are assumed to be rowfinite and source-free. Actually, we focus on a special class of rank k graphs - single-vertex rank k graphs.

Single-vertex k-graphs, at first sight, seem to be a very special class of k-graphs. It turns out that they are a rather intriguing class to study. They have been systematically studied in the literature, e.g., $[14,15,16,17]$. There are close connections with the well-known Yang-Baxter equation [55].

Let $\left\{\epsilon_{1}, \ldots, \epsilon_{\mathrm{k}}\right\}$ be the standard basis of $\mathbb{N}^{\mathrm{k}}$, and $\Lambda$ be a single-vertex rank k graph. For $1 \leq i \leq \mathrm{k}$, write $\Lambda^{\epsilon_{i}}:=\left\{\mathbf{x}_{\mathfrak{s}}^{i}: \mathfrak{s} \in\left[n_{i}\right]\right\}$, where $n_{i}=\left|\Lambda^{\epsilon_{i}}\right|$. It follows from the factorization property of $\Lambda$ that, for $1 \leq i<j \leq \mathrm{k}$, there is a permutation $\theta_{i j} \in S_{n_{i} \times n_{j}}$ satisfying the following $\theta$-commutation relations

$$
\mathbf{x}_{\mathfrak{s}}^{i} \mathbf{x}_{\mathfrak{t}}^{j}=\mathbf{x}_{\mathfrak{t}^{\prime}}^{j} \mathbf{x}_{\mathfrak{s}^{\prime}}^{i} \quad \text { if } \quad \theta_{i j}(\mathfrak{s}, \mathfrak{t})=\left(\mathfrak{s}^{\prime}, \mathfrak{t}^{\prime}\right)
$$

To emphasize $\theta$-commutation relations involved, this single-vertex k -graph $\Lambda$ is denoted as $\Lambda_{\theta}$ in this paper. So $\Lambda_{\theta}$ is the following (unital) semigroup

$$
\Lambda_{\theta}=\left\langle\mathbf{x}_{\mathfrak{s}}^{i}: \mathfrak{s} \in\left[n_{i}\right], 1 \leq i \leq \mathrm{k} ; \mathbf{x}_{\mathfrak{s}}^{i} \mathbf{x}_{\mathfrak{t}}^{j}=\mathbf{x}_{\mathfrak{t}^{\prime}}^{j} \mathbf{x}_{\mathfrak{s}^{\prime}}^{i} \text { whenever } \theta_{i j}(\mathfrak{s}, \mathfrak{t})=\left(\mathfrak{s}^{\prime}, \mathfrak{t}^{\prime}\right)\right\rangle^{+}
$$

which is also occasionally written as

$$
\Lambda_{\theta}=\left\langle\mathbf{x}_{\mathfrak{s}}^{i}: \mathfrak{s} \in\left[n_{i}\right], 1 \leq i \leq \mathrm{k} ; \theta_{i j}, 1 \leq i<j \leq \mathrm{k}\right\rangle^{+}
$$

One should notice that $\Lambda_{\theta}$ has the cancellation property due to the unique factorization property. It follows from the $\theta$-commutation relations that every element $w \in \Lambda_{\theta}$ has the normal form $w=\mathbf{x}_{u_{1}}^{1} \cdots \mathbf{x}_{u_{\mathrm{k}}}^{\mathrm{k}}$ for some $\mathbf{x}_{u_{i}}^{i} \in \Lambda_{\theta}^{\epsilon_{i} \mathrm{~N}}(1 \leq i \leq \mathrm{k})$. Here we use the multi-index notation: $\mathbf{x}_{u_{i}}^{i}=\mathbf{x}_{\mathfrak{s}_{1}}^{i} \cdots \mathbf{x}_{\mathfrak{s}_{n}}^{i}$ if $u_{i}=\mathfrak{s}_{1} \cdots \mathfrak{s}_{n}$ with all $\mathfrak{s}_{i}$ 's in $\left[n_{i}\right]$.

For $\mathrm{k}=2$, every permutation $\theta \in S_{n_{1} \times n_{2}}$ determines a single-vertex rank 2 graph. But for $\mathrm{k} \geq 3, \theta=\left\{\theta_{i j}: 1 \leq i<j \leq \mathrm{k}\right\}$ determines a rank k graph if and only if it satisfies a cubic condition (see, e.g., $[16,22]$ for its definition). This cubic condition exactly provides interplay between k-graphs and the Yang-Baxer equation ([55]).

Here are some examples of single-vertex k-graphs which will be used later.
Example 2.1. (Trivial permutation) For $1 \leq i<j \leq \mathrm{k}$, let $\theta_{i j}$ be the trivial permutation: $\theta_{i j}(s, t)=(s, t)$ for all $s \in\left[n_{i}\right]$ and $t \in\left[n_{j}\right]$. Then clearly $\Lambda_{\theta}$ is a k-graph for all $\mathrm{k} \geq 1$, which is written as $\Lambda_{\mathrm{id}}$.

Example 2.2. (Division permutation) Let $\theta_{i j}$ be defined by $\theta_{i j}(s, t)=\left(s^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right)$, where $s^{\prime} \in\left[n_{i}\right]$ and $t^{\prime} \in\left[n_{j}\right]$ are the unique integers such that $s+t n_{i}=t^{\prime}+s^{\prime} n_{j}$. One can check that this determines a k-graph for any $\mathrm{k} \geq 1$ (see, e.g., [38]), denoted as $\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}$.

In particular, if $n_{i}=n$ for all $1 \leq i \leq \mathrm{k}$, then $\theta$ coincides with the flip commutation relation: $\theta_{i j}(s, t)=(t, s)$.
Example 2.3. ("Trivial" case) Let $n_{i}=1$ for all $1 \leq i \leq \mathrm{k}$. Then $\theta_{i j}$ has to be the trivial commutation relation, which is the same as the division commutation relation. This is a special case of both Examples 2.1 and 2.2.

Very surprisingly, this case is not trivial at all when it is equipped with self-similar actions! It is extremely interesting and related to Furstenberg's $\times p, \times q$ conjecture. See Section 4.2 below.
2.2. Self-similar single-vertex k-graph $\mathbf{C}^{*}$-algebras. To unify the treatments of $[30,31]$ and $[44,46]$, self-similar graphs and their $\mathrm{C}^{*}$-algebras naturally arise in [21] and are well studied there. Later, they are generalized to higher rank cases in [40], and are further studied in $[39,41]$.

Since this paper mainly focuses on single-vertex k-graphs, we adapt the notions of $[39,40]$ to our setting and simplify them accordingly.

Let $\Lambda_{\theta}$ be a single-vertex k-graph. A bijection $\pi: \Lambda_{\theta} \rightarrow \Lambda_{\theta}$ is called an automorphism of $\Lambda_{\theta}$ if $\pi$ preserves the degree map $d .{ }^{1}$ Denote by $\operatorname{Aut}\left(\Lambda_{\theta}\right)$ the automorphism group of $\Lambda$.

Let $G$ be a (discrete countable) group. We say that $G$ acts on $\Lambda_{\theta}$ if there is a group homomorphism $\varphi$ from $G$ to $\operatorname{Aut}\left(\Lambda_{\theta}\right)$. For $g \in G$ and $\mu \in \Lambda_{\theta}$, we often simply write $\varphi_{g}(\mu)$ as $g \cdot \mu$.

Definition 2.4 ([39, Definition 3.2]). Let $\Lambda_{\theta}$ be a single-vertex k-graph, $G$ be a group acting on $\Lambda_{\theta}$, and $G \times \Lambda_{\theta} \rightarrow G,(g, \mu) \mapsto g \rrbracket_{\mu}$ be a given map. Then we call $\left(G, \Lambda_{\theta}\right)$ a self-similar k-graph if the following properties hold true:
(i) $g \cdot(\mu \nu)=(g \cdot \mu)\left(\left.g\right|_{\mu} \cdot \nu\right)$ for all $g \in G, \mu, \nu \in \Lambda_{\theta}$;
(ii) $\left.g\right|_{v}=g$ for all $g \in G, v \in \Lambda_{\theta}^{0}$;
(iii) $\left.g\right|_{\mu \nu}=\left.g\right|_{\mu} \rrbracket_{\nu}$ for all $g \in G, \mu, \nu \in \Lambda_{\theta}$;
(iv) $\left.1_{G}\right|_{\mu}=1_{G}$ for all $\mu \in \Lambda_{\theta}$;
(v) $\left.(g h)\right|_{\mu}=\left.g\right|_{h \cdot \mu} h \rrbracket_{\mu}$ for all $g, h \in G, \mu \in \Lambda_{\theta}$.

In this case, we also say that $\Lambda_{\theta}$ is a self-similar k-graph over $G$, and that $G$ acts on $\Lambda_{\theta}$ self-similarly.

Definition 2.5. A self-similar k-graph $\left(G, \Lambda_{\theta}\right)$ is said to be pseudo-free if $g \cdot \mu=\mu$ and $\left.g\right|_{\mu}=1_{G}$ implies $g=1_{G}$ for all $g \in G$ and $\mu \in \Lambda_{\theta}$.

Definition 2.6 ([39, Definition 3.8]). Let $\left(G, \Lambda_{\theta}\right)$ be a self-similar k-graph. The self-similar k-graph $C^{*}$-algebra $\mathcal{O}_{G, \Lambda_{\theta}}$ is defined to be the universal unital $\mathrm{C}^{*}$-algebra generated by a family of unitaries $\left\{u_{g}\right\}_{g \in G}$ and a family of isometries $\left\{s_{\mu}: \mu \in \Lambda_{\theta}\right\}$ satisfying
(i) $u_{g h}=u_{g} u_{h}$ for all $g, h \in G$;
(ii) $s_{\mu} s_{\nu}=s_{\mu \nu}$ for all $\mu, \nu \in \Lambda_{\theta}$;
(iii) $\sum_{\mu \in \Lambda_{\theta}^{0}} s_{\mu} s_{\mu}^{*}=I$ for all $\mathbf{n} \in \mathbb{N}^{\mathrm{k}}$;
(iv) $u_{g} s_{\mu}=s_{g \cdot \mu} u_{g \rrbracket_{\mu}}$ for all $g \in G$ and $\mu \in \Lambda_{\theta}$.

Let us record the following result ([40, Propositions 3.12 and 5.10]), which will be used later without mentioning.

Proposition 2.7. Let $\left(G, \Lambda_{\theta}\right)$ be a self-similar k-graph. Then
(i) the linear span of $\left\{s_{\mu} u_{g} s_{\nu}^{*}: \mu, \nu \in \Lambda_{\theta}, g \in G\right\}$ is a dense $*$-subalgebra of $\mathcal{O}_{G, \Lambda_{\theta}}$;
(ii) The k-graph $C^{*}$-algebra $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{\theta}}$ naturally embeds into $\mathcal{O}_{G, \Lambda_{\theta}}$;
(iii) $G$ and $\mathrm{C}^{*}(G)$ embed into $\mathcal{O}_{G, \Lambda_{\theta}}$, provided that $\left(G, \Lambda_{\theta}\right)$ is pseudo-free and $G$ is amenable.

As in [40], let $\gamma$ be the gauge action of $\mathbb{T}^{\mathrm{k}}$ on $\mathcal{O}_{\mathbb{Z}, \Lambda_{\theta}}$ :

$$
\gamma_{\mathbf{t}}\left(s_{\mu} u_{g} s_{\nu}^{*}\right)=\mathbf{t}^{d(\mu)-d(\nu)} s_{\mu} u_{g} s_{\nu}^{*}
$$

for all $\mu, \nu \in \Lambda_{\theta}, g \in \mathbb{Z}$, and $\mathbf{t} \in \mathbb{T}^{\mathrm{k}}$. The fixed point algebra, $\mathcal{O}_{\mathbb{Z}, \Lambda_{\theta}}^{\gamma}$, of $\gamma$ is generated by the standard generators $s_{\mu} u_{g} s_{\nu}^{*}$ with $d(\mu)=d(\nu)$. We often write $\mathcal{F}$ to stand for $\mathcal{O}_{\mathbb{Z}, \Lambda_{\theta}}^{\gamma}$. More

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{1}$ In general, an automorphism on $\Lambda_{\theta}$ is not necessarily a semigroup automorphism on $\Lambda_{\theta}$, as a semigroup.

generally, for $\mathbf{n} \in \mathbb{N}^{\mathbf{k}}$, we define a mapping on $\mathcal{O}_{\mathbb{Z}, \Lambda_{\theta}}$ by

$$
\Phi_{\mathbf{n}}(x)=\int_{\mathbb{T}^{\mathbf{k}}} \mathbf{t}^{-\mathbf{n}} \gamma_{\mathbf{t}}(x) d \mathbf{t} \text { for all } x \in \mathcal{O}_{\mathbb{Z}, \Lambda_{\theta}}
$$

Note that for $\mu, \nu \in \Lambda_{\theta}, g \in G$ we have

$$
\Phi_{\mathbf{n}}\left(s_{\mu} u_{g} s_{\nu}^{*}\right)= \begin{cases}s_{\mu} u_{g} s_{\nu}^{*} & \text { if } d(\mu)-d(\nu)=\mathbf{n} \\ 0 & \text { otherwise }\end{cases}
$$

In particular, $\mathcal{O}_{\mathbb{Z}, \Lambda_{\theta}}^{\gamma}=\operatorname{Ran} \Phi_{0}$. Also $\Phi_{0}$ is a faithful conditional expectation from $\mathcal{O}_{\mathbb{Z}, \Lambda_{\theta}}$ onto $\mathcal{O}_{\mathbb{Z}, \Lambda_{\theta}}^{\gamma}$.

We end this subsection by briefly recalling the periodicity of $\left(G, \Lambda_{\theta}\right)$. Let $\left(G, \Lambda_{\theta}\right)$ be a selfsimilar k-graph. For $\mu, \nu \in \Lambda_{\theta}, g \in G$, the triple $(\mu, g, \nu)$ is called cycline if $\mu(g \cdot x)=\nu x$ for all $x \in s(\nu) \Lambda^{\infty}$. Clearly, every triple $\left(\mu, 1_{G}, \mu\right)(\mu \in \Lambda)$ is cycline. Those cycline triples are said to be trivial. An infinite path $x \in \Lambda_{\theta}^{\infty}$ is said to be $G$-aperiodic if, for $g \in G, \mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q} \in \mathbb{N}^{\mathbf{k}}$ with $g \neq 1_{G}$ or $\mathbf{p} \neq \mathbf{q}$, we have $\sigma^{\mathbf{p}}(x) \neq g \cdot \sigma^{\mathbf{q}}(x)$; otherwise, $x$ is called $G$-periodic. $\left(G, \Lambda_{\theta}\right)$ is said to be aperiodic if there exists a $G$-aperiodic path $x \in \Lambda_{\theta}^{\infty}$; and periodic otherwise.
Theorem 2.8 (Li-Yang [39]). $\left(G, \Lambda_{\theta}\right)$ is aperiodic $\Longleftrightarrow$ all cycline triples are trivial.

# 2.3. Right LCM semigroup $\mathrm{C}^{*}$-algebras and their boundary quotient $\mathrm{C}^{*}$-algebras. 

Let us recall some basics about right LCM semigroups and their $\mathrm{C}^{*}$-algebras from [6]. Let $P$ be a discrete left-cancellative semigroup. We say $P$ is a right LCM semigroup if any two elements $x, y \in P$ with a right common multiple have a right least common multiple $z \in P$. Equivalently, $P$ is right LCM if, for any $x, y \in P$, the intersection $x P \cap y P$ is either empty or equal to $z P$ for some $z \in P$.

For a right LCM semigroup $P$, its $\mathrm{C}^{*}$-algebra $\mathrm{C}^{*}(P)$ defined in [42] can be greatly simplified as follows: $\mathrm{C}^{*}(P)$ is the universal $\mathrm{C}^{*}$-algebra generated by isometries $\left\{v_{p}: p \in P\right\}$ and projections $\left\{e_{p P}: p \in P\right\}$ satisfying

$$
v_{p} v_{q}=v_{p q}, v_{p} e_{q P} v_{p}^{*}=e_{p q P}, e_{P}=1, e_{\varnothing}=0, e_{p P} e_{q P}=e_{p P \cap q P}
$$

for all $p, q \in P$.
Recall that a subset $F \subseteq P$ is called a foundation set if it is finite and for each $p \in P$ there exists $q \in F$ such that $p P \cap q P \neq \varnothing$. Then the boundary quotient $\mathcal{Q}(P)$ of $\mathrm{C}^{*}(P)$ is the universal $\mathrm{C}^{*}$-algebra generated by isometries $\left\{v_{p}: p \in P\right\}$ and projections $\left\{e_{p P}: p \in P\right\}$ satisfying the relations in (1) and

$$
\prod_{p \in F}\left(1-e_{p P}\right)=0 \text { for every foundation set } F \subseteq P
$$

2.4. Semigroups from self-similar actions. Let $\Lambda_{\theta}$ be a single-vertex k-graph. By $\Lambda^{\epsilon}$, we denote the set of all edges of $\Lambda_{\theta}: \Lambda^{\epsilon}=\bigcup_{i=1}^{\mathrm{k}}\left\{e \in \Lambda: d(e)=\epsilon_{i}\right\}$. Suppose that $\mathbb{Z}=\langle a\rangle$ acts on $\Lambda_{\theta}$ self-similarly. Then one can naturally associate a semigroup to the self-similar k-graph $\left(\mathbb{Z}, \Lambda_{\theta}\right)$ as follows:

$$
\mathrm{S}_{\mathbb{N}, \Lambda_{\theta}}:=\left\langle a, e:\left.a e=a \cdot e a\right|_{e} \quad \text { if } e \in \Lambda_{\theta}^{\epsilon} \text { and }\left.a\right|_{e} \geq 0,\right.$ $\left.a e\left(\left.a\right|_{e}\right)^{-1}=a \cdot e \quad \text { if } e \in \Lambda_{\theta}^{\epsilon} \text { and }\left.a\right|_{e}<0, \quad e \in \Lambda_{\theta}^{\epsilon}\right\rangle^{+} .$
$$

This is the semigroup we focus on in this paper. Because of its importance, it deserves a name.

Definition 2.9. The semigroup $\mathrm{S}_{\mathbb{N}, \Lambda_{\theta}}$ defined in (2) is called the semigroup of the self-similar k-graph $\left(\mathbb{Z}, \Lambda_{\theta}\right)$.

Here are another semigroup and a group which are closely related to the semigroup $\mathrm{S}_{\mathbb{N}, \Lambda_{\theta}}$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{S}_{\mathbb{Z}, \Lambda_{\theta}}:=\left\langle a, a^{-1}, e: a e=a \cdot e a\right|_{e}, e \in \Lambda_{\theta}^{\epsilon}\right\rangle^{+} \\
& \mathrm{G}_{\mathbb{Z}, \Lambda_{\theta}}:=\left\langle a, e: a e=a \cdot e a\right|_{e}, e \in \Lambda_{\theta}^{\epsilon}\right\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

Remark 2.10. Some remarks are in order.
(i) We should mention that $\mathbb{N}$ used in $\mathrm{S}_{\mathbb{N}, \Lambda_{\theta}}$ emphasizes that only non-negative integers from $\mathbb{Z}$ are involved, although the self-similar graph $\left(\mathbb{Z}, \Lambda_{\theta}\right)$ is considered.
(ii) We have intended to call $\mathrm{S}_{\mathbb{N}, \Lambda_{\theta}}$ the self-similar monoid/semigroup of $\left(\mathbb{Z}, \Lambda_{\theta}\right)$. But the term 'self-similar monoids/semigroups' is already used in the literature for a very different meaning (see, e.g., [3]), and is similar to the notion of groups over self-similar k-graphs given in [39].
(iii) At first glance, it seems that the semigroup $\mathrm{S}_{\mathbb{N}, \Lambda_{\theta}}$ has been considered in [38, Section 3]. But one should notice that it is required that the restriction map is surjective in [38]. This is a rather strong condition. Most semigroups $\mathrm{S}_{\mathbb{N}, \Lambda_{\theta}}$ studied in this paper are not covered there.

# 3. RANK 1 CASE: MORE THAN GBS SEMigROUPS 

For $1 \leq n \in \mathbb{N}$, let $\mathrm{E}_{n}$ denote the single-vertex (directed) graph with $n$ edges. Suppose that $\left(\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n}\right)$ is a self-similar graph. Assume that the action of $\mathbb{Z}$ on the edge set $\mathrm{E}_{n}^{1}$ has $\kappa$ orbits $\mathcal{E}_{i}:=\left\{e_{s}^{i}: a \cdot e_{s}^{i}=e_{s+1 \bmod n_{i}}^{i}, s \in\left[n_{i}\right]\right\}$ for each $1 \leq i \leq \kappa$. Thus

$$
n=\sum_{i=1}^{\kappa} n_{i} \quad \text { and } \quad \mathrm{E}_{n}^{1}=\bigsqcup_{i=1}^{\kappa} \mathcal{E}_{i}
$$

For $1 \leq i \leq \kappa$, let

$$
m_{i}:=\sum_{s \in\left[n_{i}\right]}\left.a\right|_{e_{s}^{i}} \quad \text { and } \quad m:=\sum_{i=1}^{\kappa} m_{i}
$$

Clearly the self-similar action of $\left(\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n}\right)$ induces a self-similar graph $\left(\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n_{i}}\right)$ for each $1 \leq i \leq$ $\kappa$. Conversely, if there is a self-similar action $\mathbb{Z}$ on each $\mathrm{E}_{n_{i}}$, then these $\kappa$ self-similar graphs $\left(\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n_{i}}\right)$ determine a self-similar graph $\left(\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n}\right)$.

So, in the rank 1 case, one can rewrite

$$
\mathrm{S}_{\mathbb{N}, \mathrm{E}_{n}}:=\left\langle a, e \in \mathrm{E}_{n}^{1}: a e=\left.a \cdot e a\right|_{e} \quad \text { if } a\right|_{e} \geq 0\right\rangle^{+}
$$

Before going further, we should mention that [44] also deals with the rank 1 case. But there, in terms of our terminology, the action of $\mathbb{Z}$ on the infinite path space $\mathrm{E}_{n}^{\infty}$ is assumed to be faithful. This in particular implies that the self-similar graph $\left(\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n}\right)$ is aperiodic. Thus this eliminates all interesting (periodic) self-similar graphs (cf. Propositions 3.18, 3.22, 3.23, and Theorem 3.20 below).

Throughout this section, we assume that

$$
m_{i} \neq 0 \text { for all } 1 \leq i \leq \kappa
$$

This condition assures that the self-similar graph $\left(\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n}\right)$ is pseudo-free (Lemma 3.11), which is required in $[21,39,40]$.
Remark 3.1. It is worth mentioning that, under the assumptions $(\dagger), \mathrm{S}_{\mathbb{N}, \mathrm{E}_{n}}$ is embedded into the group $\mathrm{G}_{\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n}}([1])$.

A special class of self-similar graphs is worth mentioning for later use.
Example 3.2 $((n, m)$-odometer $\mathrm{E}(n, m))$. For $1 \leq n \in \mathbb{N}$ and $0 \neq m \in \mathbb{Z}$, an $(n, m)$-odometer is a self-similar graph $\left(\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n}\right)$ with the action and restriction given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
a \cdot e_{s} & = \begin{cases}e_{s+1} & \text { if } 0 \leq s<n-1 \\
e_{0} & \text { if } s=n-1\end{cases} \\
\left.a\right|_{e_{s}} & = \begin{cases}0 & \text { if } 0 \leq s<n-1 \\
a^{m} & \text { if } s=n-1\end{cases}
\end{aligned}
$$

The $(n, m)$-odometer is denoted as $\mathrm{E}(n, m)$. The case of $m=1$ yields the classical odometers which have been extensively studied in the literature (see, e.g., [45] and the references therein).

In the sequel, we provide two examples of important semigroups which can be realized as semigroups of self-similar graphs.
Example 3.3 (BS semigroups). For $1 \leq n \in \mathbb{N}$ and $0 \neq m \in \mathbb{Z}$, the Baumslag-Solitar (BS) semigroup is

$$
\mathrm{BS}^{+}(n, m):=\left\langle a, b \left\lvert\, \begin{array}{l}
a^{n} b=b a^{m} \\
a^{n} b a^{-m}=b
\end{array}\right.\right.\right.
$$

The semigroup $\mathrm{BS}^{+}(n, m)$ can be realized as the semigroup of an $(n, m)$-odometer.
From now on, we use the semigroups $\mathrm{BS}^{+}(n, m)$ and $(n, m)$-odometer interchangeably.
Example 3.4 (GBS semigroups). As the name indicates, this example generalizes BS semigroups in Example 3.3. Let $1 \leq \kappa \in \mathbb{N} \cup\{\infty\}$. For $1 \leq n_{i} \in \mathbb{N}$ and $0 \neq m_{i} \in \mathbb{Z}(1 \leq i \leq \kappa)$, the generalized Baumslag-Solitar (GBS) semigroup is

$$
\mathrm{GBS}_{\kappa}^{+}\left(n_{i}, m_{i}\right):=\left\langle a, b_{i} \left\lvert\, \begin{array}{l}
a^{n_{i}} b_{i}=b_{i} a^{m_{i}} \\
a^{n_{i}} b_{i} a^{-m_{i}}=b_{i}
\end{array}\right.\right. \text { if } m_{i}>0, \quad 0, \quad 1 \leq i \leq \kappa\rangle^{+}
$$

The GBS semigroup $\mathrm{GBS}_{\mathrm{E}}^{+}\left(n_{i}, m_{i}\right)$ can also be realized as the semigroup of a self-similar graph as follows. Let E be the single-vertex directed graph with the edge set $\left\{e_{s}^{i}: 1 \leq i \leq\right.$ $\left.\kappa, s \in\left[n_{i}\right]\right\}$. To each $1 \leq i \leq \kappa$, we associate an $\left(n_{i}, m_{i}\right)$-odometer. Then $\operatorname{GBS}_{\kappa}^{+}\left(n_{i}, m_{i}\right) \cong$ $\mathrm{S}_{\mathrm{N}, \mathrm{E}}$.

Therefore, semigroups of self-similar graphs encompass GBS semigroups.
Remark 3.5. In this remark, let us mention some connections with the literature.
(i) BS semigroups usually provide a nice class of examples or counter-examples for some properties (e.g., [7, 25]). They have been attracting a lot of operator algebraists' attention recently. For instance, in [50], the boundary quotient of the semigroup $\mathrm{C}^{*}$ algebra $\mathrm{BS}^{+}(n, m)$ is first investigated via the $\mathrm{C}^{*}$-algebra for a category of paths. In [11], the KMS states of the semigroup $\mathrm{C}^{*}$-algebra of quasi-lattice ordered BS semigroups are studied. This is generalized to all BS semigroups later in [7].

(ii) Very recently, in [10] Chen-Li study the $\mathrm{C}^{*}$-algebras for a class of semigroups, which are graphs of semigroups which are constructed very similarly to graphs of groups in [49]. There is some intersection: For instance, their semigroups encompass GBS semigroups. However, theirs do not include all semigroups $\mathrm{S}_{\mathbb{Z}, \Lambda_{\theta}}$. Most importantly, theirs do not include any 'genuine' higher rank BS semigroups studied in Section 4 below.
3.1. Some basic properties. The two lemmas below will be used frequently. One can prove the first one by simple calculations, and the second one by applying Remark 3.1. Their proofs are omitted here.
Lemma 3.6. Let $\left(\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n}\right)$ be a self-similar graph. Then, for $\ell \in \mathbb{Z}, 1 \leq i \leq \kappa$, and $p \in\left[n_{i}\right]$, one has
(i) $a^{\ell n_{i}+p} \cdot e_{s}^{i}=e_{(s+p) \bmod n_{i}}^{i}$;
(ii) $\left.a^{\ell n_{i}+p}\right|_{e_{s}^{i}}= \begin{cases}a^{\ell n_{i}} & \text { if } p=0, \\ a^{\ell m_{i}} \prod_{q=0}^{p-1} a\right|_{e_{(s+q) \bmod n_{i}}}^{i} & \text { if } 0<p<n_{i}-1 .\end{cases}$

Lemma 3.7. Every element $x \in \mathrm{~S}_{\mathbb{N}, \mathrm{E}_{n}}$ has a unique representation $x=e_{\mu} a^{\ell}$ for some $\mu \in \mathrm{E}_{n}^{*}$ and $\ell \in \mathbb{Z}$.
Proposition 3.8. $\mathrm{S}_{\mathbb{N}, \mathrm{E}_{n}}$ is right LCM.
Proof. Consider $e_{\mu} a^{k}$ and $e_{\nu} a^{\ell}$ in $\mathrm{S}_{\mathbb{N}, \mathrm{E}_{n}}$. It is not hard to see that they have a right common upper bound if, and only if either $e_{\mu}=e_{\nu} e_{\tilde{\mu}}$ for some $e_{\tilde{\mu}} \in \mathrm{E}_{n}^{*}$ or $e_{\nu}=e_{\mu} e_{\tilde{\nu}}$ for some $e_{\tilde{\nu}} \in \mathrm{E}_{n}^{*}$. WLOG we assume that $e_{\nu}=e_{\mu} e_{\tilde{\nu}}$ for some $e_{\tilde{\nu}} \in \mathrm{E}_{n}^{*}$. Let $e_{\alpha}:=a^{-k} \cdot e_{\tilde{\nu}}$. Then one can show the following: If $\left.a^{\ell} \geq a^{k}\right|_{e_{\alpha}}$ (resp. $\left.a^{\ell}<a^{k}\right|_{e_{\alpha}}$ ), then $e_{\nu} a^{\ell}$ (reps. $\left.e_{\nu} a^{k}\right|_{e_{\alpha}}$ ) is a least right common upper bound of $e_{\mu} a^{k}$ and $e_{\nu} a^{\ell}$ (in $\mathrm{S}_{\mathbb{N}, \mathrm{E}_{n}}$ ).
Remark 3.9. If $\left.a\right|_{e} \geq 0$ for all $e \in \mathrm{E}_{n}$, then $\mathrm{S}_{\mathbb{N}, \mathrm{E}_{n}}$ is a Zappa-Szép product of the semigroups $\mathbb{N}$ and $\mathbb{F}_{n}^{+}([6])$.

Since $\mathrm{S}_{\mathbb{N}, \mathrm{E}_{n}}$ is right LCM, from Subsection 2.3 and the analysis above, one has the following Corollary 3.10. $\mathcal{Q}\left(\mathrm{S}_{\mathbb{N}, \mathrm{E}_{n}}\right) \cong \mathcal{O}_{\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n}} \cong \mathcal{Q}\left(\mathrm{S}_{\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n}}\right)$.
Proof. By Proposition 3.8, the sets $\{a\}$ and $\left\{e_{i}: i \in[n]\right\}$ are foundation sets of $\mathrm{S}_{\mathbb{N}, \mathrm{E}_{n}}$. Then the map

$$
\mathcal{Q}\left(\mathrm{~S}_{\mathbb{N}, \mathrm{E}_{n}}\right) \rightarrow \mathcal{O}_{\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n}}, v_{e_{\mu} a^{\ell}} \mapsto s_{e_{\mu}} u_{a^{\ell}}, e_{e_{\mu} a^{\ell} \mathrm{S}_{\mathbb{N}, \mathrm{E}_{n}}} \mapsto s_{e_{\mu}} s_{e_{\mu}}^{*}
$$

yields an isomorphism. The proof of $\mathcal{Q}\left(\mathrm{S}_{\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n}}\right) \cong \mathcal{O}_{\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n}}$ is even simpler.
3.2. Pseudo-freeness of $\left(\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n}\right)$. Let $\left(\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n}\right)$ be a self-similar graph satisfying our standing assumption $(\dagger)$.
Lemma 3.11. The self-similar graph $\left(\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n}\right)$ is pseudo-free.
Proof. This follows from Lemma 3.6. In fact, suppose that $g \cdot \mu=\mu$ and $\left.g\right|_{\mu}=0$. If $|\mu|=1$, it then follows from Lemma 3.6 and the assumption $(\dagger)$ that $g=0$. Now suppose that $g \cdot \mu=\mu$ and $\left.g\right|_{\mu}=0$ with $|\mu|=k$ imply $g=0$. Let $g \cdot\left(\mu e_{s}^{i}\right)=\mu e_{s}^{i}$ and $\left.g\right|_{\mu e_{s}^{i}}=0$ for some edge $e_{s}^{i}$ in the $i$-th orbit. Then $\left.g \cdot \mu g\right|_{\mu} \cdot e_{s}^{i}=\mu e_{s}^{i} \Longrightarrow g \cdot \mu=\mu$ and $\left.g\right|_{\mu} \cdot e_{s}^{i}=e_{s}^{i}$. So the latter implies $\left.g\right|_{\mu}=a^{\ell n_{i}}$ for some $\ell \in \mathbb{Z}$. But also $\left.g\right|_{\mu e_{s}^{i}}=0$ implies that $\left.0=\left.g\right|_{\mu}\right|_{e_{s}^{i}}=\left.a^{\ell n_{i}}\right|_{e_{s}^{i}}=a^{\ell m_{i}}$. Hence $\ell=0$ as $m_{i} \neq 0$. Therefore $g \cdot \mu=\mu$ and $\left.g\right|_{\mu}=0$. By our inductive assumption, we have $g=0$. This proves the pseudo-freeness of $\left(\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n}\right)$.

Remark 3.12. Lemma 3.11 is no longer true if $m_{i}=0$ for some $1 \leq i \leq \kappa$. For example, consider the self-similar graph $\left(\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{2}\right)$ with $a e_{1}=e_{2} a$ and $a e_{2}=e_{1} a^{-1}$. Then $a^{2} e_{i}=e_{i}$ for $i=1,2$, and $\left.a^{2}\right|_{e_{i}}=0$. Clearly, this self-similar graph $\left(\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{2}\right)$ is not pseudo-free.
3.3. The periodicity of $\left(\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n}\right)$. In this subsection, we study the periodicity of self-similar graphs $\left(\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n}\right)$ in detail. We first analyze the case when $\kappa=1$, and then use it to study the general case.

Recall that $\kappa$ is the number of orbits of $\mathbb{Z}$ on $\mathrm{E}_{n}$.
3.3.1. The case of $\kappa=1$.

Proposition 3.13. If $\kappa=1$, then $\left(\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n}\right)$ is periodic if and only if $n \mid m$.
Proof. Suppose that $m=n \ell$ for some $\ell \in \mathbb{Z}$. Let $x=e_{i_{1}} e_{i_{2}} \cdots \in \mathrm{E}_{n}^{\infty}$ be an infinite path. Repeatedly applying Lemma 3.6 gives

$$
a^{n k} \cdot x=a^{n k} \cdot e_{i_{1}} a^{n k}\left.\right|_{e_{i_{1}}} \cdot\left(e_{i_{2}} \cdots\right)=e_{i_{1}} a^{n \ell k} \cdot\left(e_{i_{2}} \cdots\right)=\cdots=x \quad \text { for all } \quad k \in \mathbb{Z}
$$

This shows that every infinite path $x \in \mathrm{E}_{n}^{\infty}$ is $\mathbb{Z}$-periodic in the sense of [40]. So $\left(\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n}\right)$ is periodic.

It remains to show that if $n \nmid m$ then $\left(\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n}\right)$ is aperiodic. To the contrary, assume that $\left(\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n}\right)$ is periodic. It follows from [39, Theorem 3.7] $\left(\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n}\right)$ has a non-trivial cycline triple $(\mu, g, \nu)$. That is, $\mu g \cdot x=\nu x$ for all $x \in \mathrm{E}_{n}^{\infty}$ with $g \neq 0$ or $\mu \neq \nu$.

Case (a): $|\mu|<|\nu|$. Then there is a unique $\nu^{\prime} \in \mathrm{E}_{n}^{*} \backslash \mathrm{E}_{n}^{0}$ such that $\nu=\mu \nu^{\prime}$. Thus $g \cdot x=\nu^{\prime} x$ and so $g \cdot x\left(0,\left|\nu^{\prime}\right|\right)=\nu^{\prime}$ for all $x \in \mathrm{E}_{n}^{\infty}$. This is impossible by noticing that $n$ has to be greater than 1 .

Case (b): $|\mu|>|\nu|$. Since $x \in \mathrm{E}_{n}^{\infty}$ is arbitrary, we replace $x$ with $g^{-1} \cdot x$ and then apply Case (a).

Case (c): $|\mu|=|\nu|$. Then $\mu=\nu$ and $g \cdot x=x$ for all $x \in \mathrm{E}_{n}^{\infty}$. Let $d:=\operatorname{gcd}(m, n)>0$. Write $m=d m_{0}$ and $n=d n_{0}$. Since $n \nmid m$, we have $n_{0} \nmid m_{0}$. Write $x=e_{i_{1}} e_{i_{2}} \cdots$ with $i_{j} \in[n]$. Then

$$
g \cdot\left(e_{i_{1}} e_{i_{2}} \cdots\right)=e_{i_{1}} e_{i_{2}} \cdots \Longrightarrow g \cdot e_{i_{1}}=\left.e_{i_{1}}, g\right|_{e_{i_{1}}} \cdot e_{i_{2}}=e_{i_{2}}, \ldots
$$

Hence there is a sequence $\left\{k_{i}\right\}_{i \geq 1} \subseteq \mathbb{Z}$ of (non-zero) integers such that

$$
g=a^{k_{1} n}, a^{k_{1} m}=a^{k_{2} n}, a^{k_{2} m}=a^{k_{3} n}, a^{k_{3} m}=a^{k_{4} n}, \ldots
$$

So

$$
k_{1} m=k_{2} n, k_{2} m=k_{3} n, \ldots
$$

imply

$$
k_{1} m_{0}=k_{2} n_{0}, k_{2} m_{0}=k_{3} n_{0}, \ldots
$$

Thus one has that $m_{0}^{p} k_{1}=n_{0}^{p} k_{p+1}$ for all $p \geq 1$. In particular $n_{0}^{p} \mid k_{1}$ for all $p \geq 1$ as $\operatorname{gcd}\left(m_{0}, n_{0}\right)=1$. But $n \nmid m$ implies $n_{0}>1$. So $k_{1}=0$ and hence $g=0$. Then $(\mu, g, \nu)=(\mu, 0, \mu)$ is a trivial cycline triple. This is a contradiction.

Remark 3.14. Let $(G, \Lambda)$ be a self-similar k-graph. As mentioned in [40], it is easy to see that if $\Lambda$ is periodic, then $(G, \Lambda)$ is periodic. But the converse is not true. Here is a class of counter-examples: It is well-known that $\mathrm{E}_{n}$ is aperiodic if $n>1$. But Proposition 3.13 shows that $\left(\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n}\right)$ is periodic whenever $n \mid m$. Therefore, the periodicity of $(G, \Lambda)$ is more complicated than that of the ambient graph $\Lambda$.

We now determine all cycline triples of $\left(\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n}\right)$ when $\kappa=1$. Notice that all cycline triples are trivial if $\left(\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n}\right)$ is aperiodic by Theorem 2.8. Hence it suffices to consider periodic self-similar graphs $\left(\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n}\right)$.

When $n=1$, there is a unique infinite path. So the following is straightforward.
Lemma 3.15. If $n=1$, then every triple $\left(\mu, a^{\ell}, \nu\right)$ is cycline.
Proposition 3.16. Suppose that $\kappa=1, n>1$, and $\left(\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n}\right)$ is periodic. Then $(\mu, g, \nu)$ is cycline if and only if $\mu=\nu$ and $g=a^{\ell n}$ for some $\ell \in \mathbb{Z}$.

Proof. "If" part is clear. For the "Only if" part, assume that $(\mu, g, \nu)$ is cycline. Then

$$
\mu g \cdot x=\nu x \text { for all } x \in \mathrm{E}_{n}^{\infty}
$$

If $|\mu|=|\nu|$, then $\mu=\nu$ and $g \cdot x=x$ for all $x \in \mathrm{E}_{n}^{\infty}$. As in the proof of Proposition 3.13, one can see that $g=a^{\ell n}$ for some $\ell \in \mathbb{Z}$.

If $|\mu| \neq|\nu|$, WLOG, $|\nu|>|\mu|$. Then $\nu=\mu \nu^{\prime}$ for some $\nu^{\prime} \in \mathrm{E}_{n}^{*} \backslash \mathrm{E}_{n}^{0}$ and $g \cdot x=\nu^{\prime} x$. This is impossible as $n>1$.

Combining [40, Theorem 6.6, Theorem 6.13] with Corollary 3.10 yields
Theorem 3.17. $\mathcal{Q}\left(\mathrm{S}_{\mathfrak{N}, \mathrm{E}_{n}}\right)$ with $\kappa=1$ satisfies UCT. It is simple iff $n \nmid m$. So it is a Kirchberg algebra iff $n \nmid m$.
3.3.2. The general case. For the general $\kappa \geq 1$, we begin with a relation between the periodicity of $\left(\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n}\right)$ and that of its restrictions on orbits.

For simplification, let $\mathfrak{N}:=\operatorname{lcm}\left(n_{i}: 1 \leq i \leq \kappa\right)$.
Proposition 3.18. $\left(\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n}\right)$ is periodic, if and only if the restriction $\left(\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n_{i}}\right)$ is periodic for each $1 \leq i \leq \kappa$, if and only if $n_{i} \mid m_{i}$ for every $1 \leq i \leq \kappa$.

Proof. If there is $1 \leq i \leq \kappa$ such that $n_{i} \nmid m_{i}$, then $\left(\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n_{i}}\right)$ is aperiodic by Proposition 3.16. Then clearly $\left(\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n}\right)$ is aperiodic.

Now let us assume that $n_{i} \mid m_{i}$ for all $1 \leq i \leq \kappa$. Say $m_{i}=n_{i} \widetilde{m}_{i}$ with $0 \neq \widetilde{m}_{i} \in \mathbb{Z}$ for $1 \leq i \leq \kappa$. Then

$$
a^{\mathfrak{N}} e_{s_{1}}^{i_{1}} \cdots e_{s_{p}}^{i_{p}}=e_{s_{1}}^{i_{1}} \cdots e_{s_{p}}^{i_{p}} a^{\mathfrak{N} \widetilde{m}_{i_{1}} \cdots \widetilde{m}_{i_{p}}}
$$

Thus one can check that for arbitrary $x \in \mathrm{E}_{n}^{\infty}$ one has $a^{\mathfrak{N}} \cdot x=x$. Therefore, every infinite path $x$ is $\mathbb{Z}$-periodic, and so $\left(\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n}\right)$ is periodic.

We now determine all cycline triples. If $n=1$, this is provided in Lemma 3.15.
Proposition 3.19. If $\left(\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n}\right)$ is periodic with $n>1$, then $(\mu, g, \nu)$ is cycline if and only if $\mu=\nu$ and $g=a^{\ell \mathfrak{N}}$ for some $\ell \in \mathbb{Z}$.

Proof. "If" part is clear. For the "Only if" part, assume that $(\mu, g, \nu)$ is cycline. Then

$$
\mu g \cdot x=\nu x \text { for all } x \in \mathrm{E}_{n}^{\infty}
$$

If $|\mu|=|\nu|$, then $\mu=\nu$ and $g \cdot x=x$ for all $x \in \mathrm{E}_{n}^{\infty}$. It is now not hard to see that $g=a^{\ell \mathfrak{N}}$ for some $\ell \in \mathbb{Z}$.

If $|\mu| \neq|\nu|$, WLOG, $|\nu|>|\mu|$. Then $\nu=\mu \nu^{\prime}$ for some $\nu^{\prime} \in \mathrm{E}_{n}^{*} \backslash \mathrm{E}_{n}^{0}$ and $g \cdot x=\nu^{\prime} x$. This is impossible as $n>1$.

Combining [40, Theorem 6.6, Theorem 6.13] with Corollary 3.10 yields

Theorem 3.20. $\mathcal{O}_{\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n}}$ satisfies UCT. It is simple iff $n_{i} \nmid m_{i}$ for some $1 \leq i \leq \kappa$. So it is a Kirchberg algebra iff $n_{i} \nmid m_{i}$ for some $1 \leq i \leq \kappa$.

Remark 3.21. It is well-known that the roles of $n$ and $m$ in Baumslag-Solitar groups $\mathrm{BS}(n, m)$ are symmetric in the sense of $\mathrm{BS}(n, m) \cong \mathrm{BS}(m, n)$. So $\mathrm{C}^{*}(\mathrm{BS}(n, m)) \cong \mathrm{C}^{*}(\mathrm{BS}(m, n))$. However, the symmetry is lost for BS semigroups. For instance, If $0<n \neq m \in \mathbb{N}$ satisfies $n \mid m$, then $\mathcal{Q}\left(\mathrm{BS}^{+}(n, m)\right)$ is not simple while $\mathcal{Q}\left(\mathrm{BS}^{+}(m, n)\right)$ is simple.
3.4. Cartan subalgebras of $\mathcal{O}_{\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n}}$. We begin with the definition of Cartan subalgebras. Let $\mathcal{B}$ be an abelian $\mathrm{C}^{*}$-subalgebra of a given $\mathrm{C}^{*}$-algebra $\mathcal{A} . \mathcal{B}$ is called a Cartan subalgebra in $\mathcal{A}$ if
(i) $\mathcal{B}$ contains an approximate unit in $\mathcal{A}$;
(ii) $\mathcal{B}$ is a MASA;
(iii) $\mathcal{B}$ is regular: the normalizer set $N(\mathcal{B})=\left\{x \in \mathcal{A}: x \mathcal{B} x^{*} \cup x^{*} \mathcal{B} x \subseteq \mathcal{B}\right\}$ generates $\mathcal{A}$;
(iv) there is a faithful conditional expectation $\mathcal{E}$ from $\mathcal{A}$ onto $\mathcal{B}$.

In this subsection, we show that there is a canonical Cartan subalgebra for each $\mathcal{O}_{\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n}}$. It is closely related to the fixed point algebra $\mathcal{O}_{\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n}}^{\gamma}$ of the gauge action $\gamma$. However, there is an essential difference between the cases of $n=1$ and $n>1$.
3.4.1. The case of $n=1$. The case of $n=1$ is a special case of Subsection 4.4 below with $\mathrm{k}=1$ (i.e., rank 1 ), which does not use any results from this section. So we record the result below just for completeness.

In what follows, to simplify our writing, let us set $\mathcal{F}:=\mathcal{O}_{\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n}}^{\gamma}$, and $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$ to be the (relative) commutant of $\mathcal{F}$ in $\mathcal{O}_{\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n}}$.

Proposition 3.22. Keep the above notation. Then $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}=\overline{\operatorname{span}}\left\{s_{e^{p}} a^{\ell} s_{e^{q}}^{*}: m^{p}=m^{q}, \ell \in \mathbb{Z}\right\}$ and $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$ is a Cartan subalgebra of $\mathcal{O}_{\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{1}}$.

It is worth noticing that there are three possible cases for $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$ :

- If $m=1$, then $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}=\overline{\operatorname{span}}\left\{s_{e^{p}} u_{a^{\ell}} s_{e^{q}}^{*}: p, q \in \mathbb{N}, \ell \in \mathbb{Z}\right\}=\mathcal{O}_{\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{1}} \cong \mathrm{C}\left(\mathbb{T}^{2}\right)$.
- If $m=-1$, then $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}=\overline{\operatorname{span}}\left\{s_{e^{p}} u_{a^{\ell}} s_{e^{q}}^{*}: p, q \in \mathbb{N}\right.$ with $\left.p-q \in 2 \mathbb{Z}, \ell \in \mathbb{Z}\right\}$.
- If $m \neq \pm 1$, then $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}=\mathcal{F}$.
3.4.2. The case of $n>1$. Recall that $\mathfrak{N}=\operatorname{lcm}\left(n_{i}: 1 \leq i \leq \kappa\right)$ and $n=\sum_{i=1}^{\kappa} n_{i}$.

Proposition 3.23. If $n>1$, then the cycline $C^{*}$-subalgebra $\mathcal{M}:=\mathrm{C}^{*}\left(s_{\mu} u_{a^{\ell \mathrm{m}}} s_{\mu}^{*}: \mu \in \mathrm{E}_{n}^{*}, \ell \in\right.$ $\mathbb{Z})$ is a MASA in $\mathcal{O}_{\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n}}$.

Proof. We first show that $\mathcal{M}$ is abelian. Compute

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(s_{\mu} u_{a^{K \mathfrak{N}}} s_{\mu}^{*}\right)\left(s_{\nu} u_{a^{L \mathfrak{N}}} s_{\nu}^{*}\right) \\
& =\left\{\begin{array}{ll}
s_{\mu} u_{a(K+L) \mathfrak{N}} s_{\mu}^{*} & \text { if } \mu=\nu \\
s_{\mu} u_{a^{K \mathfrak{N}}} s_{\nu^{\prime}} u_{a^{L \mathfrak{N}}} s_{\nu}^{*}=s_{\mu} s_{\nu^{\prime}} u_{a^{K \mathfrak{N}}}\left\lvert\,_{\nu^{\prime}} u_{a^{L \mathfrak{N}}} s_{\nu}^{*}=s_{\nu} u_{a^{K \mathfrak{N}}}\right. & \text { if } \nu=\mu \nu^{\prime} \\
s_{\mu} u_{a^{K \mathfrak{N}}} s_{\mu^{\prime}}^{*} u_{a^{L \mathfrak{N}}} s_{\nu}^{*}=s_{\mu} u_{a^{K \mathfrak{N}}} u_{\left.\left(a^{-L n}\right]_{a^{L \mathfrak{N}} \mu^{\prime}}\right)^{-1}} s_{\mu^{\prime}}^{*} s_{\nu}^{*}=s_{\mu} u_{a^{K \mathfrak{N}}} u_{a^{L \mathfrak{N}}}\left\lvert\,_{\mu^{\prime}} s_{\mu}^{*} \quad \text { if } \mu=\nu \mu^{\prime}\right. \\
0 & \text { otherwise. }
\end{array}\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

Similar calculations yield

$$
\left(s_{\nu} u_{a^{L \mathfrak{N}}} s_{\nu}^{*}\right)\left(s_{\mu} u_{a^{K \mathfrak{N}}} s_{\mu}^{*}\right)= \begin{cases}s_{\nu} u_{a(K+L) \mathfrak{N}} s_{\nu}^{*} & \text { if } \mu=\nu \\ s_{\nu} u_{a^{L \mathfrak{N}}} u_{a^{K \mathfrak{N}}}\left\lvert\,_{\nu^{\prime}} s_{\nu}^{*}\right. & \text { if } \nu=\mu \nu^{\prime} \\ s_{\mu} u_{a^{L \mathfrak{N}}}\left\lvert\,_{\mu^{\prime}} u_{a^{K \mathfrak{N}}} s_{\mu}^{*}\right. & \text { if } \mu=\nu \mu^{\prime} \\ 0 & \text { otherwise }\end{cases}
$$

Thus $\mathcal{M}$ is abelian.
As in [39], let $\mathcal{G}_{\mathbb{Z}, \mathbf{E}_{n}}$ be the groupoid associated to the self-similar graph $\left(\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n}\right)$. It follows from [39, Lemma 5.2] and Proposition 3.19 that $\operatorname{Iso}\left(\mathcal{G}_{\mathbb{Z}, \mathbf{E}_{n}}\right)^{\circ}=\bigcup_{\mu \in \mathbf{E}_{\mathbb{Z}}, l \in \mathbb{Z}} Z\left(\mu, a^{\ell \mathfrak{N}}, \mu\right)$. Also notice that $\mathcal{M} \cong \mathrm{C}^{*}\left(\operatorname{Iso}\left(\mathcal{G}_{\mathbb{Z}, \mathbf{E}_{n}}\right)^{\circ}\right)$. So $\mathrm{C}^{*}\left(\operatorname{Iso}\left(\mathcal{G}_{\mathbb{Z}, \mathbf{E}_{n}}\right)^{\circ}\right)$ is abelian. Hence, by [9, Corollary 5.4], $\mathcal{M}$ is a MASA.

Remark 3.24. By Lemma 3.15, when $n=1$, the cycline subalgebra of $\mathcal{O}_{\mathbb{Z}, \mathbf{E}_{1}}$ coincides with $\mathcal{O}_{\mathbb{Z}, \mathbf{E}_{1}}$, which is generally not abelian. So Proposition 3.23 does not hold true for $n=1$.

Remark 3.25. Keep the same notation in the proof above. If $\operatorname{Iso}\left(\mathcal{G}_{\mathbb{Z}, \mathbf{E}_{n}}\right)^{\circ}$ is closed, then applying [5, Corollary 4.5] one can conclude that $\mathcal{M}$ is Cartan in $\mathcal{O}_{\mathbb{Z}, \mathbf{E}_{n}}$. But, unfortunately, $\operatorname{Iso}\left(\mathcal{G}_{\mathbb{Z}, \mathbf{E}_{n}}\right)^{\circ}$ needn't be closed in general.
3.5. Some old examples revisited. Recall the flip (single-vertex) rank 2 graphs

$$
\Lambda_{\text {flip }}=\left\langle\mathbf{e}_{i}, \mathbf{f}_{j}: \mathbf{e}_{i} \mathbf{f}_{j}=\mathbf{f}_{i} \mathbf{e}_{j}, i, j \in[n]\right\rangle^{+}(n \geq 2)
$$

and the square rank 2 graph

$$
\Lambda_{\text {square }}=\left\langle\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{j}: \mathbf{x}_{i} \mathbf{y}_{j}=\mathbf{y}_{i+1} \mathbf{x}_{j}, i, j \in[2]\right\rangle^{+}
$$

Example 3.26. In [11], it is shown that $\mathcal{Q}\left(\mathrm{BS}^{+}(n, n)\right) \cong \mathrm{C}(\mathbb{T}) \otimes \mathcal{O}_{n}$. From what we have obtained so far, we can prove this by relating to rank 2 graphs. In fact, we have

$$
\mathcal{Q}\left(\mathrm{BS}^{+}(n, n)\right) \cong \mathrm{C}(\mathbb{T}) \otimes \mathcal{O}_{n} \cong \mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{\text {flip }}}
$$

To see this, we construct an explicit isomorphism from $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{\text {flip }}}$ onto $\mathcal{Q}\left(\mathrm{BS}^{+}(n, n)\right)$. Let $\pi$ : $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{\text {flip }}} \rightarrow \mathcal{Q}\left(\mathrm{BS}^{+}(n, n)\right)$ be the homomorphism determined by

$$
s_{\mathbf{e}_{i}} \mapsto E_{i}:=s_{e_{i}}, s_{\mathbf{f}_{j}} \mapsto F_{j}:=u_{a^{n}} s_{e_{j}}(i, j \in[n])
$$

It is easy to see that $E_{i} F_{j}=F_{i} E_{j}$ as $u_{a^{n}}$ is in the center of $\mathcal{Q}\left(\mathrm{BS}^{+}(n, n)\right)$. Also $\pi$ is surjective as from $a e_{i}=e_{i+1}(0 \leq i \leq n-2)$ and $a e_{n-1}=e_{0} a^{n}$ one has

$$
\sum_{i=0}^{n-1} u_{a} s_{e_{i}} s_{e_{i}}^{*}=\sum_{i=0}^{n-2} s_{e_{i+1}} s_{e_{i}}^{*}+s_{e_{0}} u_{a^{n}} s_{e_{n-1}}^{*}=\sum_{i=0}^{n-2} s_{e_{i+1}} s_{e_{i}}^{*}+u_{a^{n}} s_{e_{0}} s_{e_{n-1}}^{*}=\sum_{i=0}^{n-2} s_{e_{i+1}} s_{e_{i}}^{*}+F_{0} s_{e_{n-1}}^{*}
$$

Conversely, define $\rho: \mathcal{Q}\left(\mathrm{BS}^{+}(n, n)\right) \rightarrow \mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{\text {flip }}}$ by

$$
s_{e_{i}} \mapsto s_{\mathbf{e}_{i}}, u_{a} \mapsto \sum_{i=0}^{n-2} s_{\mathbf{e}_{i+1}} s_{\mathbf{e}_{i}}^{*}+s_{\mathbf{f}_{0}} s_{\mathbf{e}_{n-1}}^{*}
$$

Then $\rho$ determines a homomorphism. Also one can check that $\pi$ and $\rho$ are the inverse to each other. Therefore one has $\mathcal{Q}\left(\mathrm{BS}^{+}(n, n)\right) \cong \mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{\text {flip }}}$, which is also isomorphic to $\mathrm{C}(\mathbb{T}) \otimes \mathcal{O}_{n}$ by $[15]$.

Example 3.27. In this example, through $\mathrm{BS}^{+}(2,2)$, we are able to show that $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{\text {square }}} \cong$ $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{\text {flip }}}$, which seems unclear in [15] although both $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{\text {flip }}}$ and $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{\text {square }}}$ are well-studied there.

Let $W:=s_{\mathbf{e}_{1}} s_{\mathbf{e}_{0}}^{*}+s_{\mathbf{f}_{0}} s_{\mathbf{e}_{1}}^{*}$. Then $W^{2}=s_{\mathbf{f}_{0}} s_{\mathbf{e}_{0}}^{*}+s_{\mathbf{f}_{1}} s_{\mathbf{e}_{1}}^{*}$. Define $\pi: \mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{\text {square }}} \rightarrow \mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{\text {flip }}}$ via

$$
s_{\mathbf{x}_{0}} \mapsto s_{\mathbf{e}_{0}}, s_{\mathbf{x}_{1}} \mapsto s_{\mathbf{e}_{1}} W^{*}, s_{\mathbf{y}_{0}} \mapsto W s_{\mathbf{e}_{0}}, s_{\mathbf{y}_{1}} \mapsto W s_{\mathbf{e}_{1}} W^{*}
$$

Then one can verify that $\pi$ is a homomorphism.
Let $F:=s_{\mathbf{y}_{1}} s_{\mathbf{x}_{1}}^{*}+s_{\mathbf{y}_{0}} s_{\mathbf{x}_{0}}^{*}$. Then $F^{2}=\sum_{i, j \in[2]} s_{\mathbf{y}_{i} \mathbf{y}_{j}} s_{\mathbf{x}_{(i+1) \mathbf{x}_{j}}^{*}}^{*}$. Let $\rho: \mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{\text {flip }}} \rightarrow \mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{\text {square }}}$ be defined as

$$
s_{\mathbf{e}_{0}} \mapsto s_{\mathbf{x}_{0}}, s_{\mathbf{e}_{1}} \mapsto s_{\mathbf{x}_{1}} F, s_{\mathbf{f}_{0}} \mapsto F^{2} s_{\mathbf{x}_{0}}=s_{\mathbf{x}_{0}} F^{2}, s_{\mathbf{f}_{1}} \mapsto F^{2} s_{\mathbf{x}_{1}} F=s_{\mathbf{x}_{1}} F^{3}
$$

Then $\rho$ is a homomorphism. Moreover, $\pi$ and $\rho$ are the inverse to each other, and $\rho(W)=F$ and $\pi(F)=W$.

# 4. Rank k case: more than higher rank Baumslag-Solitar Semigroups 

In this section, we first propose a notion of higher rank BS semigroups $\Lambda_{\theta}(\mathfrak{n}, \mathfrak{m})$. We then briefly describe how higher rank BS semigroups relate to Furstenberg's $\times p, \times q$ conjecture. Our main focus here are two cases $-\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}\left(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}\right)$ and $\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}\left(\mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}, \mathfrak{m}\right)$. For $\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}\left(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}\right)$, it is related to products of odometers studied in [38]. Applying some results in [38, 39], one can easily characterize the simplicity of $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}\left(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}\right)}$ and see that the cycline subalgebra is Cartan in $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}\left(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}\right)}$. But, here, we first show the fixed point algebra $\mathcal{F}$ of the gauge action $\gamma$ is a BunceDeddens algebra, and so $\mathcal{F}$ has a unique faithful tracial state $\tau$. Then composing with the conditional expectation $\Phi$ from $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}\left(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}\right)}$ onto $\mathcal{F}$ yields a state $\omega=\tau \circ \Phi$. We then study the associated von Neumann algebra $\pi_{\omega}\left(\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}\left(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}\right)}\right)^{\prime \prime}$ in the same vein of $[52,53]$. More precisely, we provide some characterizations of when $\pi_{\omega}\left(\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}\left(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}\right)}\right)^{\prime \prime}$ is a factor, and further obtain its type. For $\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}\left(\mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}, \mathfrak{m}\right)$, it is intimately related to Furstenberg's $\times p, \times q$ conjecture. In this case, we obtain a canonical Cartan for $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}\left(\mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}, \mathfrak{m}\right)}$, which is generally a proper subalgebra of its cycline subalgebra. We will continue studying $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}\left(\mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}, \mathfrak{m}\right)}$ and its relative(s) in a forthcoming paper.
4.1. Higher rank Baumslag-Solitar semigroups. Consider k given self-similar graphs $\left(\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n_{i}}\right)$ with $\mathrm{E}_{n_{i}}=\left\{\mathbf{x}_{\mathfrak{s}}^{i}: s \in\left[n_{i}\right]\right\}(1 \leq i \leq \mathrm{k})$. Suppose that $\mathbf{x}_{\mathfrak{s}}^{i}$ 's satisfy the commutation relations $\theta_{i j}\left(\mathbf{x}_{\mathfrak{s}}^{i}, \mathbf{x}_{\mathfrak{i}}^{j}\right)=\left(\mathbf{x}_{\mathfrak{i}^{\prime}}^{j}, \mathbf{x}_{\mathfrak{s}^{\prime}}^{i}\right)$ for $1 \leq i<j \leq \mathrm{k}$. Applying [38, Proposition 4.1], one has

Proposition 4.1. Keep the same notation. The k self-similar graphs $\left(\mathbb{Z}, \mathrm{E}_{n_{i}}\right)$ with the commutation relations $\theta_{i j}$ 's determine a self-similar k -graph $\left(\mathbb{Z}, \Lambda_{\theta}\right)$ if and only if

$$
\left(a \cdot \mathbf{x}_{\mathfrak{s}}^{i}\right)\left(\left.a\right|_{\mathbf{x}_{\mathfrak{s}}^{i}} \cdot \mathbf{x}_{\mathfrak{i}}^{j}\right)=\left(a \cdot \mathbf{x}_{\mathfrak{i}^{\prime}}^{j}\right)\left(\left.a\right|_{\mathbf{x}_{\mathfrak{s}^{\prime}}^{j}} \cdot \mathbf{x}_{\mathfrak{s}^{\prime}}^{i}\right)
$$

for all $1 \leq i<j \leq \mathrm{k}, \mathfrak{s} \in\left[n_{i}\right], \mathfrak{t} \in\left[n_{j}\right]$.
Based on Example 3.3, it is reasonable to introduce the following notion.
Definition 4.2. A self-similar k -graph obtained from $\left(n_{i}, m_{i}\right)$-odometers with the commutation relations $\theta_{i j}$ 's is called a rank $\mathrm{k} B S$ semigroup, denoted as $\Lambda_{\theta}\left(\left(n_{1}, \ldots, n_{\mathrm{k}}\right),\left(m_{1}, \ldots, m_{\mathrm{k}}\right)\right)$, or simply $\Lambda_{\theta}(\mathfrak{n}, \mathfrak{m})$ if the context is clear. The ambient k -graph is still written as $\Lambda_{\theta}$.

Here are some examples of higher rank BS semigroups.

Example 4.3. A standard product of odometers studied in [38] is a rank k BS semigroup induced from $\left(n_{i}, 1\right)$-odometers $\mathrm{E}\left(n_{i}, 1\right)(1 \leq i \leq \mathrm{k})$ with the division commutation relations (refer to Example 2.2 for d). So it is of the form $\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}\left(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}\right)$.
Example 4.4. Consider $\left(n_{i}, m_{i}\right)$-odometers with the trivial permutation $\theta_{i j}(1 \leq i<j \leq \mathrm{k})$ (see Example 2.1). Then they induce a rank k BS semigroup if and only if $n_{i}=1$ for each $1 \leq i \leq \mathrm{k}$. In fact, the condition (4) in Proposition 4.1 implies $n_{i}=1$ for all $1 \leq i \leq \mathrm{k}$. Then the trivial relation is the same as the division commutation relation. The rank k BS semigroup obtained in this case is of the form $\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}\left(\mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}, \mathfrak{m}\right)$.
Example 4.5. Suppose that $n_{i}=n$ for all $1 \leq i \leq \mathrm{k}$, and that $\theta_{i j}$ is the division permutation. Then one necessarily has $\theta_{i j}(s, t)=(t, s)$. One can check that this yields a rank k BS semigroup if and only if either $m_{i}=m_{j}$ for all $1 \leq i, j \leq \mathrm{k}$, or $n \mid m_{i}$ for all $1 \leq i \leq \mathrm{k}$. These are rank k BS semigroups of the form $\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}((n, \ldots, n),(m, \ldots, m))$, or $\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}\left((n, \ldots, n),\left(n \widetilde{m}_{1}, \ldots, n \widetilde{m}_{\mathrm{k}}\right)\right)$.

So the class obtained in Example 4.4 is a special case here with $n=1$.
In the sequel, we provide some interesting $\mathrm{C}^{*}$-algebras studied in the literature, which can be realized from higher rank BS semigroups.
(i) It is shown in [38] that the Cuntz algebra $\mathcal{Q}_{\mathbb{N}}$ is isomorphic to the boundary quotient of a semigroup of the form in Example 4.3.
(ii) For $2 \leq p \in \mathbb{N}$, the $p$-adic $\mathrm{C}^{*}$-algebra $\mathcal{Q}_{p}$ can also be recovered from a semigroup of the form in Example 4.3 (cf. [38] for $p=2$ in terms of standard product of odometers).
(iii) $\mathcal{Q}_{\mathbb{N}}$ can be also realized as a boundary quotient of the left $a x+b$ semigroup $\mathbb{N} \rtimes \mathbb{N}^{\times}$ studied in [34]. The $\mathrm{C}^{*}$-algebra of $\mathbb{N} \rtimes \mathbb{N}^{\times}$itself is also related to higher rank BS semigroups.
(iv) The boundary $\partial \mathcal{T}\left(\mathbb{N}^{\times} \ltimes \mathbb{N}\right)$ of the right $a x+b$ semigroup $\mathbb{N}^{\times} \ltimes \mathbb{N}$ is a boundary quotient of a higher-rank BS semigroup of the form given in Example 4.4.
(v) The $\mathrm{C}^{*}$-algebra $\mathcal{O}\left(E_{n, m}\right)$ studied by Katsura in [30] is isomorphic to $\mathcal{O}_{\mathrm{E}(n, m)}$ (see Examples 3.2 and 3.3).

Remark 4.6. The $\mathrm{C}^{*}$-algebras of both the left $a x+b$ semigroup $\mathbb{N} \rtimes \mathbb{N}^{\times}$and the right $a x+b$ semigroup $\mathbb{N}^{\times} \ltimes \mathbb{N}$ are related to higher rank BS semigroups. This will be studied elsewhere.
4.2. Relation to Furstenberg's $\times p, \times q$ conjecture. We first give a very brief introduction on Furstenberg's $\times p, \times q$ conjecture. For all undefined notions or any further information, refer to $[8,23,24,48]$.

Let $2 \leq p, q \in \mathbb{N}$ be multiplicatively independent, i.e., $\frac{\ln p}{\ln q} \notin \mathbb{Q}$. Define $T_{p}: \mathbb{T} \rightarrow \mathbb{T}$ by $T_{p}(z)=z^{p}$ for all $z \in \mathbb{T}$. Similarly for $T_{q}$. A subset of $\mathbb{T}$ is said to be $\times p, \times q$-invariant if it is invariant under both $T_{p}$ and $T_{q}$. Furstenberg classifies all closed $\times p, \times q$-invariant subsets of $\mathbb{T}$ in [23]: Such a subset is either finite or $\mathbb{T}$ itself. Then he conjectures the following:
Conjecture (Furstenberg's $\times p, \times q$ conjecture). An ergodic $\times p, \times q$-invariant Borel probability measure of $\mathbb{T}$ is either finitely supported or the Lebesgue measure.

According to our best knowledge, this conjecture is still open. The best known result so far is the following theorem, which is proved by Rudolph when $p$ and $q$ are coprime in [47], and later improved by Johnson in [28].

Theorem (Rudolph-Johnson). If $\mu$ is an ergodic $\times p, \times q$-invariant measure on $\mathbb{T}$, then either both entropies of $T_{p}$ and $T_{q}$ with respect to $\mu$ are 0 , or $\mu$ is the Lebesgue measure.

When both entropies of $T_{p}$ and $T_{q}$ with respect to $\mu$ are 0 , Furstenberg's $\times p, \times q$ conjecture is reduced to studying the $\mathrm{C}^{*}$-algebra $\mathrm{C}^{*}(G)$ of the group $G$, where

$$
G:=\left\langle s, t, z: s t=t s, s z=z^{p} s, t z=z^{q} t\right\rangle
$$

It turns out that $\mathrm{C}^{*}(G) \cong \mathrm{C}^{*}\left(\mathbb{Z}\left[\frac{1}{p q}\right]\right) \rtimes \mathbb{Z}^{2} \cong \mathrm{C}^{*}\left(\mathbb{Z}\left[\frac{1}{p q}\right] \rtimes \mathbb{Z}^{2}\right)$. In [24], the representation theory of $\mathrm{C}^{*}\left(\mathbb{Z}\left[\frac{1}{p q}\right]\right) \rtimes \mathbb{Z}^{2}$ is studied. In particular, the authors focus on which kind of its representations are induced by $\times p, \times q$-invariant measures on $\mathbb{T}$. Later, the following equivalence is shown in [8]: Furstenberg's $\times p, \times q$ conjecture holds true if and only if the canonical trace is the only faithful extreme tracial state on $\mathrm{C}^{*}(G) \cong \mathrm{C}^{*}\left(\mathbb{Z}\left[\frac{1}{p q}\right] \rtimes \mathbb{Z}^{2}\right)$.

Our purpose here is to connect Furstenberg's conjecture with higher rank BS semigroups. For this, from (5) one has

$$
t^{-1} s^{-1}=s^{-1} t^{-1}, z^{-1} s^{-1}=s^{-1} z^{-p}, z^{-1} t^{-1}=t^{-1} z^{-q}
$$

Let $\tilde{G}$ be the group

$$
\tilde{G}:=\left\langle\tilde{s}, \tilde{t}, \tilde{z}: \tilde{t} \tilde{s}=\tilde{s} \tilde{t}, \tilde{z} \tilde{s}=\tilde{s} \tilde{z}^{p}, \tilde{z} \tilde{t}=\tilde{t} \tilde{z}^{q}\right\rangle
$$

Thus $G \cong \tilde{G}$ and so $\mathrm{C}^{*}(G) \cong \mathrm{C}^{*}(\tilde{G})$. The upshot by doing so is $\mathrm{C}^{*}(G) \cong \mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{d}((1,1),(p, q))}$.
Now return to (5) again. Let $G^{+}$be the corresponding semigroup

$$
G^{+}:=\left\langle s, t, z: s t=t s, s z=z^{p} s, t z=z^{q} t\right\rangle^{+}
$$

Then we claim that $\mathcal{Q}\left(G^{+}\right) \cong \mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{d}((p, q),(1,1))}$. In fact, let $e_{i}:=z^{i} s$ and $f_{j}:=z^{j} t$ for $i \in[p]$ and $j \in[q]$. Then $s t=t s \Longleftrightarrow e_{0} f_{0}=f_{0} e_{0}$. For $k \in[p]$ and $\ell \in[q]$, let $k^{\prime} \in[p]$ and $\ell^{\prime} \in[q]$ be the unique ones such that $k+\ell p=\ell^{\prime}+k^{\prime} q$. Then we have

$$
e_{k} f_{\ell}=z^{k} s z^{\ell} t=z^{k} z^{\ell p} s t=z^{\ell^{\prime}} z^{k^{\prime} q} t s=z^{\ell^{\prime}} t z^{k^{\prime}} s=f_{\ell^{\prime}} e_{k^{\prime}}
$$

Thus there is a homomorphism

$$
\pi: \mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{d}((p, q),(1,1))}=\mathcal{O}_{\mathbb{Z}, \Lambda_{d}} \rightarrow \mathcal{Q}\left(G^{+}\right), s_{\mathbf{x}_{1}^{1}} \mapsto v_{e_{i}}, s_{\mathbf{x}_{2}^{2}} \mapsto v_{f_{j}}, u_{a} \mapsto v_{z}
$$

which is an isomorphism as it has an inverse given by

$$
v_{s} \mapsto s_{\mathbf{x}_{0}^{1}}, v_{t} \mapsto s_{\mathbf{x}_{0}^{2}}, v_{z} \mapsto u_{a}
$$

Hence $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{d}((p, q),(1,1))} \cong \mathcal{Q}\left(G^{+}\right)$.
To sum up, we have shown that

$$
\mathrm{C}^{*}(G) \cong \mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{d}((1,1),(p, q))} \text { and } \mathcal{Q}\left(G^{+}\right) \cong \mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{d}((p, q),(1,1))}
$$

Based on the above, in what follows, we focus on two extreme, but rather interesting, classes of higher rank BS semigroups: $\Lambda_{d}\left(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}\right)$ with $\mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}} \leq \mathfrak{n} \in \mathbb{N}^{\mathrm{k}}$ and $\Lambda_{d}\left(\mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}, \mathfrak{m}\right)$ with $m_{i} \neq 0$ for all $1 \leq i \leq \mathrm{k}$.

From now on, to unify our notation, the set $\left\{0,1 \neq p_{i} \in \mathbb{Z}: 1 \leq i \leq \mathrm{k}\right\}$ is said to be multiplicatively independent if there is no $\mathbf{0} \neq q \in \mathbb{Z}^{\mathrm{k}}$ such that $\prod_{i=1}^{\mathrm{k}} p_{i}^{q_{i}}=1$. When all $p_{i}$ 's are also $\geq 1,\left\{p_{i}: 1 \leq i \leq \mathrm{k}\right\}$ is multiplicatively independent if and only if $\left\{\ln p_{i}: 1 \leq i \leq \mathrm{k}\right\}$ is rationally independent.

4.3. The case of $\mathfrak{m}=\mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}$. The $\mathrm{C}^{*}$-algebra of the self-similar $\mathrm{k}$-graph $\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}\left(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}\right)$ is studied in [38]. It is shown there that $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}\left(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}\right)}$ is simple if and only if $\left\{n_{i}: 1 \leq i \leq \mathrm{k}\right\}$ is multiplicatively independent, and that its cycline subalgebra is Cartan by [39, Theorem 5.6]. In what follows, we identify the center of $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{d}\left(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}\right)}$, which is overlooked in [38, 39]. A useful lemma first:

Lemma 4.7. (i) Let $\mu, \nu \in \Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}^{\mathbf{p}}\left(\mathfrak{p} \in \mathbb{N}^{\mathrm{k}}\right)$ and $m \in \mathbb{Z}$. Then there is $\ell \in \mathbb{Z}$ such that $\nu a^{m}=a^{\ell} \mu$.
(ii) $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}\left(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}\right)}=\overline{\operatorname{span}}\left\{u_{a^{m}} s_{\alpha} s_{\beta}^{*}: m \in \mathbb{Z}, \alpha, \beta \in \Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}\right\}$.

Proof. (i) We first prove the lemma holds true for the classical odometer action $\mathrm{E}(n, 1)$. We argue this by induction with respect to the lengths of $\mu$ and $\nu$. If $\mu:=e_{i}$ and $\nu:=e_{j}$. WLOG we assume that $i \geq j \in[n]$. For any $m \in \mathbb{Z}$, by Lemma 3.6 one can verify that $a^{m n+i-j} \nu=\mu a^{m}$. Assume that this is true for any $m \in \mathbb{Z}$ and all $\mu, \nu \in \mathrm{E}_{n}^{*}$ with $|\mu|=|\nu| \leq k$. Now consider $e_{s} \mu$ and $e_{t} \nu$ with $|\mu|=|\nu|=k$. Let $m \in \mathbb{Z}$. By our inductive assumption, we have $e_{s} \mu a^{m}=e_{s} a^{\ell^{\prime}} \nu=a^{\ell} e_{t} \nu$ for some $\ell^{\prime}, \ell \in \mathbb{Z}$. This proves the $\mathrm{E}(n, 1)$ case.

Now return to $\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}$. Let $\mu, \nu \in \Lambda_{d}$ with $d(\mu)=d(\nu)=\mathbf{p} \in \mathbb{N}^{\mathrm{k}}$. Then by the unique factorization property $\mu=\mu_{1} \cdots \mu_{\mathrm{k}}$ and $\nu=\nu_{1} \cdots \nu_{\mathrm{k}}$ with $\mu_{i}, \nu_{i} \in \Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}^{\mu_{i} \nu_{i}}$ for $1 \leq i \leq \mathrm{k}$. Then for any $m \in \mathbb{Z}$, apply the above to $\mu_{\mathrm{k}} a^{m}$ in $\mathrm{E}\left(n_{\mathrm{k}}, 1\right)$, there is $\ell_{\mathrm{k}} \in \mathbb{Z}$ such that $\mu a^{m}=\mu_{1} \cdots \mu_{\mathrm{k}-1} a^{\ell_{\mathrm{k}}} \nu_{\mathrm{k}}$. Repeatedly using the above gives $\mu a^{m}=a^{\ell} \nu$ for some $\ell \in \mathbb{Z}$.
(ii) This follows from (i) and Proposition 2.7 (i).

By [39, Theorem 7.5] (or Appendix there), $\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}\left(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}\right)$ and $\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}$ share the same periodicity $\left\{\mathbf{p} \in \mathbb{Z}^{\mathrm{k}}: \mathfrak{n}^{\mathbf{p}}=1\right\}$. Thus, for each pair $(\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}) \in \mathbb{N}^{\mathrm{k}} \times \mathbb{N}^{\mathrm{k}}$ with $\mathfrak{n}^{\mathbf{p}}=\mathfrak{n}^{\mathbf{q}}$, there is a bijection $\phi_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}: \Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}^{\mathbf{p}} \rightarrow \Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}^{\mathbf{q}}$ satisfying

$$
\mu \nu=\phi_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}(\mu) \phi_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}^{-1}(\nu), \phi_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}^{-1}(\nu) \phi_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}(\mu)=\nu \mu
$$

for every pair $(\mu, \nu) \in \Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}^{\mathbf{p}} \times \Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}^{\mathbf{q}}([16$, Theorem 7.1]) (or [26, Section 5]). Let

$$
V_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}:=\sum_{\mu \in \Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}^{\mathbf{p}}} s_{\mu} s_{\phi_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}(\mu)}^{*}
$$

By ([16, Theorem 4.9]), each $V_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}$ is a unitary in $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}\left(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}\right)}$.
Proposition 4.8. The center of $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}\left(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}\right)}$ is given by

$$
\mathcal{Z}\left(\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}\left(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}\right)}\right)=\mathrm{C}^{*}\left(V_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}:(\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}) \in \mathbb{N}^{\mathrm{k}} \times \mathbb{N}^{\mathrm{k}}, \mathfrak{n}^{\mathbf{p}}=\mathfrak{n}^{\mathbf{q}}\right)
$$

In particular, $\mathcal{Z}\left(\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}\left(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}\right)}\right)$ is trivial, if and only if $\left\{n_{i}: 1 \leq i \leq \mathrm{k}\right\}$ is multiplicatively independent.

Proof. Suppose that $A \in \mathcal{Z}\left(\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}\left(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}\right)}\right)$. Then by Proposition 2.7, one has $A \in \mathcal{Z}\left(\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}}\right)$. But $\mathcal{Z}\left(\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}}\right)=\mathrm{C}^{*}\left(V_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}:(\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}) \in \mathbb{N}^{\mathrm{k}} \times \mathbb{N}^{\mathrm{k}}, \mathfrak{n}^{\mathbf{p}}=\mathfrak{n}^{\mathbf{q}}\right)([16])$.

It remains to show that each $V_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}$ is indeed in $\mathcal{Z}\left(\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}\left(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}\right)}\right)$. This has been proved in [16, Theorem 4.9]. In what follows, we prove this by invoking Lemma 4.7.

We first show that $u_{a}$ commutes with $V_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}$. Then on one hand one has

$$
a \cdot(\mu \nu)=a \cdot\left(\phi_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}(\mu) \phi_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}^{-1}(\nu)\right) \Longrightarrow a\left.\cdot \mu a\right|_{\mu} \cdot \nu=a \cdot \phi_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}(\mu) a|_{\phi(\mu)} \cdot \phi_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}^{-1}(\nu)
$$

On the other hand, we have

$$
\left.a \cdot \mu a\right|_{\mu} \cdot \nu=\phi_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}(a \cdot \mu) \phi_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}^{-1}\left(\left.a\right|_{\mu} \cdot \nu\right)
$$

Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left.a^{-1} \cdot \phi_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}(\mu)\left.a^{-1}\right|_{\phi_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}(\mu)} \cdot \phi_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}^{-1}(\nu)=\phi_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}\left(a^{-1} \cdot \mu\right) \phi_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}^{-1}\left(\left.a^{-1}\right|_{\mu} \cdot \nu\right) \\
& \Longrightarrow a^{-1} \cdot \phi_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}(\mu)=\phi_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}\left(\left.a^{-1} \cdot \mu\right) \quad \text { and } \quad\left.a^{-1}\right|_{\phi_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}(\mu)} \cdot \phi_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}^{-1}(\nu)=\phi_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}^{-1}\left(\left.a^{-1}\right|_{\mu} \cdot \nu\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Then one can easily see $g \cdot \phi_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}(\mu)=\phi_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}(g \cdot \mu)$ for any $g \in \mathbb{Z}$. Similarly, one gets from the 2nd identity of (9) that $g \cdot \phi_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}^{-1}(\nu)=\phi_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}^{-1}(g \cdot \nu)$ for any $g \in \mathbb{Z}$. Thus the 2 nd identity of (10) yields $\left.a^{-1}\right|_{\phi_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}(\mu)}=\left.a^{-1}\right|_{\mu}$, and so $\left(\left.a^{-1}\right|_{\phi_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}(\mu)}\right)^{-1}=\left(\left.a^{-1}\right|_{\mu}\right)^{-1}$. Therefore

$$
\left.a\right|_{\left.a^{-1} \cdot \phi_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}(\mu)}\right.}=\left.a\right|_{\left.a^{-1} \cdot \mu\right.}
$$

Now compute

$$
\begin{aligned}
u_{a} V_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}} & =\sum_{d(\mu)=\mathbf{p}} s_{a \cdot \mu} u_{a \mid \mu} s_{\phi_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}(\mu)}^{*}=\sum_{d(\mu)=\mathbf{p}} s_{\mu} u_{a \mid a^{-1} \cdot \mu} s_{\phi_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}\left(a^{-1} \cdot \mu\right)}^{*} \\
& =\sum_{d(\mu)=\mathbf{p}} s_{\mu} u_{a \mid a^{-1} \cdot \phi_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}(\mu)} s_{a^{-1} \cdot \phi_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}(\mu)}^{*}(\text { from (10) and (11)) } \\
& =\sum_{d(\mu)=\mathbf{p}} s_{\mu} u_{\left(\left.a^{-1}\right|_{\phi_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}(\mu)}\right)^{-1}} s_{a^{-1} \cdot \phi_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}(\mu)}^{*}=\left(\sum_{d(\mu)=\mathbf{p}} s_{\mu} s_{\phi_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}(\mu)}^{*}\right) u_{a} \\
& =V_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}} u_{a}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then

$$
\left(u_{a^{m}} s_{\alpha} s_{\beta}^{*}\right) V_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}=u_{a^{m}} V_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}} s_{\alpha} s_{\beta}^{*}=V_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}\left(u_{a^{m}} s_{\alpha} s_{\beta}^{*}\right)
$$

By Lemma 4.7 (ii), $\sum_{d(\mu)=\mathbf{p}} s_{\mu} s_{\phi_{\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}}(\mu)}^{*} \in \mathcal{Z}\left(\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{d}\left(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1}_{\mathbb{k}}\right)}\right)$.

For $\mathbf{m} \in \mathbb{N}^{\mathbf{k}}$, let $\mathcal{F}_{\mathbf{m}}:=\overline{\operatorname{span}}\left\{s_{\mu} a^{n} s_{\nu}^{*}: \mu, \nu \in \Lambda_{\left(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1}_{\mathbb{k}}\right)}\right.$ with $d(\mu)=d(\nu)=\mathbf{m}, n \in \mathbb{Z}\}$, and so $\mathcal{F}=\overline{\bigcup_{m \in \mathbb{N}^{k}} \mathcal{F}_{\mathbf{m}}} \cdot \mathbb{P} \cdot \mathbb{P}$. Also notice that, due to the Cuntz-Krieger relations, we have $\mathcal{F}=\lim _{m \in \mathbb{N}} \mathcal{F}_{m \mathbb{1}_{\mathbb{k}}}$.

Let $d:=\prod_{i=1}^{k} \prod_{p \in \mathcal{P}, p \mid n_{i}} p$, the product of all primes dividing some $n_{i}$ 's.
Lemma 4.9. $\mathcal{F}$ is a Bunce-Deddens algebra of type $d^{\infty}$. In particular, $\mathcal{F}$ has a unique faithful tracial state.

Proof. The proof below is motivated by the proof of [41, Theorem 3.16].
For $\mathbf{m} \in \mathbb{N}^{\mathbf{k}}$, let $\left\{e_{\mu, \nu}\right\}_{\mu, \nu \in \Lambda_{\mathbf{d}}^{\mathbf{m}}}$ be the matrix entries of $K\left(\ell^{2}\left(\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}^{\mathrm{m}}\right)\right) .{ }^{2}$ To simplify our notation, let $\left\{a^{n}\right\}_{n \in \mathbb{Z}}$ be the generating unitaries of $\mathrm{C}^{*}(\mathbb{Z})$. Clearly, there is a homomorphism

$$
\rho_{1}: K\left(\ell^{2}\left(\Lambda_{d}^{m \mathbb{1}_{\mathbb{k}}}\right)\right) \rightarrow \mathcal{F}_{m \mathbb{1}_{\mathbb{k}}}, e_{\mu, \nu} \mapsto s_{\mu} s_{\nu}^{*}
$$

and

$$
\rho_{2}: \mathrm{C}(\mathbb{T}) \rightarrow \mathcal{F}_{m \mathbb{1}_{\mathbb{k}}}, a^{n} \mapsto \sum_{\mu \in \Lambda_{d}^{m \mathbb{1}_{\mathbb{k}}}} s_{\mu} u_{a^{n}} s_{\mu}^{*}
$$

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{2}$ In our case, $K\left(\ell^{2}\left(\Lambda_{d}^{m}\right)\right) \cong M_{n^{m}}(\mathbb{C})$.

Some simple calculations show the images of $\rho_{1}$ and $\rho_{2}$ commute. By [43, Theorem 6.3.7], there is a homomorphism $\rho: K\left(\ell^{2}\left(\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}^{m \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}}\right)\right) \otimes \mathrm{C}^{*}(\mathbb{Z}) \rightarrow \mathcal{F}_{m \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}}{ }^{3}$ satisfying $\rho\left(e_{\mu, \nu} \otimes a^{n}\right)=s_{\mu} u_{a^{n}} s_{\nu}^{*}$. It is not hard to see that $\rho$ is also invertible and so an isomorphism.

Set $\mu_{0}:=\mathbf{x}_{0}^{1} \cdots \mathbf{x}_{0}^{\mathrm{k}}$ and $\mu_{\mathfrak{n}-\mathbb{1}}:=\mathbf{x}_{n_{1}-1}^{1} \cdots \mathbf{x}_{n_{\mathrm{k}}-1}^{\mathrm{k}}$. Embed $K\left(\ell^{2}\left(\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}^{m \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}}\right)\right) \otimes \mathrm{C}^{*}(\mathbb{Z})$ into $K\left(\ell^{2}\left(\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}^{(m+1) \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}}\right)\right) \otimes$ $\mathrm{C}^{*}(\mathbb{Z})$ as follows:

$$
e_{\mu, \nu} \otimes a^{n} \mapsto \sum_{\alpha \in \Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}^{k}} e_{\mu a^{n} \cdot \alpha, \nu \alpha} \otimes\left.a^{n}\right|_{\alpha}
$$

Notice that $\left.a\right|_{\alpha}=a$ if $\alpha=\mu_{\mathfrak{n}-\mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}}$, and $\left.a\right|_{\alpha}=0$, otherwise.
Now we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
u_{a} & =u_{a} \sum_{\mu \in \Lambda^{m} \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}} s_{\mu} s_{\mu}^{*}=\sum_{\mu \in \Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}^{m} \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}} s_{a \cdot \mu} u_{a \mid \mu} s_{\mu}^{*} \\
& =\sum_{\mu \neq \mu_{\mathrm{n}}-\mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}} s_{a \cdot \mu} s_{\mu}^{*}+s_{a \cdot \mu_{\mathrm{n}}-\mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}} u_{a} s_{\mu_{\mathrm{n}}-\mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}}^{*} \\
& =\sum_{\mu \neq \mu_{\mathrm{n}}-\mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}} s_{a \cdot \mu} s_{\mu}^{*}+s_{\mu_{0}} u_{a} s_{\mu_{\mathrm{n}}-\mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}}^{*}
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore $\mathcal{F}$ is isomorphic to a Bunce-Deddens algebra of type of $d^{\infty}$, and so it has a unique faithful tracial state ([13]).
Remark 4.10. It is worth mentioning the following: If $S:=\left\{n_{1}, \ldots, n_{\mathrm{k}}\right\} \subset \mathbb{N}$ is a set of mutually coprime natural numbers, then $\mathcal{F}$ is isomorphic to $B_{S}$ in [2].

By Lemma 4.9 and [13], $\mathcal{F}$ has a unique faithful tracial state, say $\tau$, given by

$$
\tau\left(s_{\mu} u_{a^{n}} s_{\mu}^{*}\right)=\mathfrak{n}^{-d(\mu)} \delta_{n, 0}
$$

Recall that $\Phi_{\mathbf{0}}$ is the faithful conditional expectation from $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1})}$ onto $\mathcal{F}$ via the gauge action $\gamma$ (see Subsection 2.2). Then $\omega:=\tau \circ \Phi_{\mathbf{0}}$ is a state of $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}\left(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}\right)}$.

We recall the notion of KMS states from [4] (also see [12]), and give some basic properties of KMS states for $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}\left(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}\right)}$.
Definition 4.11. Let $A$ be a $\mathrm{C}^{*}$-algebra, $\alpha$ be an action of $\mathbb{R}$ on $A$, and $A^{a}$ be the set of all analytic elements of $A$. Let $0<\beta<\infty$. A state $\tau$ of $A$ is called a $K M S_{\beta}$ state of $(A, \mathbb{R}, \alpha)$ if $\tau(x y)=\tau\left(y \alpha_{i \beta}(x)\right)$ for all $x, y \in A^{a}$.

Recall the gauge action $\gamma: \mathbb{T}^{\mathrm{k}} \rightarrow \operatorname{Aut}\left(\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}\left(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}\right)}\right)$ :

$$
\gamma_{z}\left(s_{\mu}\right)=z^{d(\mu)} s_{\mu} \text { and } \gamma_{z}\left(u_{g}\right)=u_{g} \quad \text { for all } \quad z \in \mathbb{T}^{\mathrm{k}}, \mu \in \Lambda, g \in \mathbb{Z}
$$

Let $\mathfrak{r}=\left(\ln n_{1}, \ldots, \ln n_{\mathrm{k}}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{\mathrm{k}}$. Define a strongly continuous homomorphism $\alpha^{\mathfrak{r}}: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow$ $\operatorname{Aut}\left(\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}\left(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}\right)}\right)$ by $\alpha_{\mathfrak{r}}^{\mathfrak{r}}:=\gamma_{e^{i \mu}}$. Notice that, for $\mu, \nu \in \Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}\left(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}\right), g \in \mathbb{Z}$, the function $\mathbb{C} \rightarrow$ $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1})}, \xi \mapsto e^{i \xi \mathfrak{r} \cdot(d(\mu)-d(\nu))} s_{\mu} u_{g} s_{\nu}^{*}$ is an entire function. So $s_{\mu} u_{g} s_{\nu}^{*}$ is an analytic element. By Proposition 2.7, in order to check the $\mathrm{KMS}_{\beta}$ condition, it is sufficient to check whether it is valid on the set $\left\{s_{\mu} u_{g} s_{\nu}^{*}: \mu, \nu \in \Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}\left(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}\right), g \in \mathbb{Z}\right\}$. In this subsection, we study basic properties of $\mathrm{KMS}_{\beta}$ states of the one-parameter dynamical system $\left(\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1})}, \mathbb{R}, \alpha^{\mathfrak{r}}\right)$.
Lemma 4.12. Suppose that $\left\{n_{i}: 1 \leq i \leq \mathrm{k}\right\}$ is multiplicatively independent. Then $\omega$ is the unique $K M S_{1}$ state on $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}\left(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}\right)}$.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{3}$ The tensor product $\otimes$ here could be either $\otimes_{\max }$ or $\otimes_{\min }$ as both factors are amenable.

Proof. An easy calculation shows

$$
\omega\left(s_{\mu} u_{a^{n}} s_{\nu}^{*}\right)=\delta_{\mu, \nu} \delta_{n, 0} \mathfrak{n}^{-d(\mu)}
$$

By [39, Theorems 6.11 and 6.12], $\omega$ is the unique $\mathrm{KMS}_{1}$ state of $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{d}(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1})}$ (also see [39, Theorem 7.1]).

As in $[52,53]$, let $L^{2}\left(\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{d}\left(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1}_{k}\right)}\right)$ be the GNS Hilbert space determined by the state $\omega$ : $\langle A, B\rangle:=\omega\left(A^{*} B\right)$ for all $A, B \in \mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{d}\left(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1}_{k}\right)}$.
