For $A \in \mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{d}\left(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1}_{k}\right)}$, we denote the left action of $A$ by $\pi(A): \pi(A) B=A B$ for all $B \in \mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{d}(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1})}$. Let $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{d}\left(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1}_{k}\right)}^{\mathrm{c}}$ stand for the algebra as the finite linear span of the generators $s_{\mu} u_{g} s_{\nu}^{*}$.

Define

$$
S(A):=A^{*}, F\left(s_{\mu} u_{a^{n}} s_{\nu}^{*}\right):=\mathfrak{n}^{d(\mu)-d(\nu)} s_{\nu} u_{a^{-n}} s_{\mu}^{*}, \quad \text { for } \quad A \in \mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{d}\left(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1}_{k}\right)}^{\mathrm{c}}
$$

Then $F=S^{*}$. Also, if

$$
J\left(s_{\mu} u_{a^{n}} s_{\nu}^{*}\right):=\mathfrak{n}^{\frac{d(\mu)-d(\nu)}{2}} s_{\nu} u_{a^{-n}} s_{\mu}^{*}, \Delta\left(s_{\mu} u_{a^{n}} s_{\nu}^{*}\right):=\mathfrak{n}^{d(\nu)-d(\mu)} s_{\mu} u_{a^{n}} s_{\nu}^{*}
$$

one has

$$
S=J \Delta^{\frac{1}{2}}=\Delta^{-\frac{1}{2}} J, F=J \Delta^{-\frac{1}{2}}=\Delta^{\frac{1}{2}} J
$$

Let $\pi_{\omega}\left(\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{d}\left(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1}_{k}\right)}\right)^{\prime \prime}$ be the von Neumann algebra generated by the GNS representation of $\omega$. Then $\pi_{\omega}\left(\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{d}\left(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1}_{k}\right)}\right)^{\prime \prime}$ coincides with the left von Neumann algebra of $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{d}\left(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1}_{k}\right)}^{\mathrm{c}}$.

The proof of the following theorem can now be easily adapted from $[52,53]$ combined with $[38,39]$, and is left to the interested reader.
Theorem 4.13. The following statements are equivalent:
(i) $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{d}\left(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1}_{k}\right)}$ is simple.
(ii) $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{d}}$ is simple.
(iii) $\left\{n_{i}: 1 \leq i \leq \mathrm{k}\right\}$ is multiplicatively independent.
(iv) $\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}\left(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}\right)$ is aperiodic.
(v) The ambient $\mathrm{k}$-graph $\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}$ is aperiodic.
(vi) $\pi_{\omega}\left(\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{d}\left(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1}_{k}\right)}\right)^{\prime \prime}$ is a factor.

When $\pi_{\omega}\left(\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda_{d}\left(\mathfrak{n}, \mathbb{1}_{k}\right)}\right)^{\prime \prime}$ is a factor,
$\bullet$ it is an AFD factor of type $I I I_{\frac{1}{2}}$ if $\mathrm{k}=1$; and

- it is an AFD factor of type $I I I_{1}^{\frac{1}{2}}$ if $\mathrm{k} \geq 2$.
4.4. The case of $\mathfrak{n}=\mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}$. Since there is only one edge for each color $i$, in order to ease our notation, we write $\mathbf{x}_{i}$ (instead of the notation $\mathbf{x}_{1}^{i}$ used above) for this unique edge. Thus $\mathbf{x}_{i} \mathbf{x}_{j}=\mathbf{x}_{j} \mathbf{x}_{i}$ for all $1 \leq i \neq j \leq \mathrm{k}$. Since this is the unique commutation relation on $\mathbf{x}_{i}$ 's, we denote $\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}\left(\mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}, \mathfrak{m}\right)$ simply as $\Lambda\left(\mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}, \mathfrak{m}\right)$. The ambient k -graph is just denoted as $\Lambda_{\mathbb{1}_{k}}$.

We should mention that it seems that the case of $\mathfrak{n}=\mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}$ is also studied in [39]. However, this is exactly the case which is completely ignored there. This could be due to two reasons: one is that $\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}\left(\mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}, \mathfrak{m}\right)$ is clearly not locally faithful, which is the crucial property required in [39]; the other is that this case, at first glance, seems too special.
Observation 4.14. The observations below are obvious and will be used frequently later without any further mention.
(i) For every $\mathbf{p} \in \mathbb{N}^{k}, \Lambda_{\mathbb{1}_{k}}^{\mathbf{p}}$ is a singleton: $\Lambda_{\mathbb{1}_{k}}^{\mathbf{p}}=\left\{\mathbf{x}^{\mathbf{p}}:=\mathbf{x}_{1}^{p_{1}} \cdots \mathbf{x}_{\mathrm{k}}^{p_{k}}\right\}$. Also, $s_{\mu}$ is a unitary for every $\mu \in \Lambda_{\mathbb{1}_{k}}$.

(ii) $\Lambda\left(\mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}, \mathfrak{m}\right)$ is pseudo-free. In fact, some computations show $\left.a^{n}\right|_{\mu}=a^{n \mathfrak{m}^{d(\mu)}}$ and so $\left.a^{n}\right|_{\mu}=0 \Longleftrightarrow n=0$.

Our next goal is to show that $\Lambda_{\mathrm{d}}\left(\mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}, \mathfrak{m}\right)$ has a canonical Cartan subalgebra. In particular, this canonical Cartan subalgebra is $\mathcal{F}$ if $\left\{\left|m_{i}\right|: 1 \leq i \leq \mathrm{k}\right\}$ is multiplicatively independent; it properly contains $\mathcal{F}$, otherwise.

Lemma 4.15. $\mathcal{F}=\overline{\operatorname{span}}\left\{s_{\mu} u_{a^{\ell}} s_{\mu}^{*}: \mu \in \Lambda_{\mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}}, \ell \in \mathbb{Z}\right\}=\overline{\operatorname{span}}\left\{s_{\mu}^{n} u_{a^{\ell}} s_{\mu}^{-n}: d(\mu)=\mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}, n \in \mathbb{N}, \ell \in\right.$ $\mathbb{Z}\}$.

Proof. It is known and easy to see that $\mathcal{F}=\overline{\operatorname{span}}\left\{s_{\mu} u_{a^{m}} s_{\nu}^{*} \mid \mu, \nu \in \Lambda_{\mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}}, d(\mu)=d(\nu), m \in\right.$ $\mathbb{Z}\}$. It follows from Observation 4.14 that $d(\mu)=d(\nu)$ forces $\mu=\nu$, say equal to $\mathbf{x}^{\mathbf{n}}$ for some $\mathbf{n} \in \mathbb{N}^{\mathrm{k}}$. WLOG, we assume that $n_{1}-n_{2}=l \geq 0$. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
s_{\mathbf{x}^{\mathbf{n}}} u_{a^{m}} s_{\mathbf{x}^{\mathbf{n}}}^{-1} & =s_{\mathbf{x}_{3}^{n_{3} \ldots \mathbf{x}_{k}^{n_{k}}}} s_{\mathbf{x}_{1}^{n_{1}}} s_{\mathbf{x}_{2}^{n_{2}}} u_{a^{m}} s_{\mathbf{x}_{2}^{n_{2}}}^{-1} s_{\mathbf{x}_{1}^{n_{1}}}^{1} s_{\mathbf{x}_{2}^{n_{3} \ldots \mathbf{x}_{k}^{n_{k}}}} \\
& =s_{\mathbf{x}_{3}^{n_{3}} \ldots \mathbf{x}_{k}^{n_{k}}}} s_{\mathbf{x}_{1}^{n_{1}}} s_{\mathbf{x}_{2}^{n_{2}}} s_{\mathbf{x}_{2}^{n_{2}}} u_{a^{m}}\left|{ }_{\mathbf{x}_{2}^{n_{2}}} s_{\mathbf{x}_{2}^{n_{3} \ldots \mathbf{x}_{k}^{n_{k}}}} s_{\mathbf{x}_{3}^{n_{3}} \ldots \mathbf{x}_{k}^{n_{k}}} s_{\mathbf{x}_{2}^{n_{2}}} s_{\mathbf{x}_{1}^{n_{1}}}\right. \\
& =s_{\mathbf{x}_{3}^{n_{3}} \ldots \mathbf{x}_{k}^{n_{k}}}} s_{\mathbf{x}_{1}^{n_{1}}} s_{\mathbf{x}_{2}^{n_{1}}} u_{a^{m}}\left|{ }_{\mathbf{x}_{2}^{n_{2}}} s_{\mathbf{x}_{3}^{n_{3}} \ldots \mathbf{x}_{k}^{n_{k}}} s_{\mathbf{x}_{2}^{n_{1}}}^{-1} s_{\mathbf{x}_{1}^{n_{1}}}^{-1}\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

After repeating this process, all the $\mathbf{x}_{i}$ 's will have the same exponent.
Lemma 4.16. $\mathcal{F}$ is commutative.
Proof. Compute

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(s_{\mu} u_{a^{l}} s_{\mu}^{*}\right)\left(s_{\nu} u_{a^{n}} s_{\nu}^{*}\right) & =s_{\mu} u_{a^{l}} s_{\nu} s_{\mu}^{*} u_{a^{n}} s_{\nu}^{*}\left(\text { as } s_{\mu}^{*} s_{\nu}=s_{\nu} s_{\mu}^{*}\right) \\
& =s_{\mu} s_{\nu} u_{a^{l} \mid_{\nu}}\left(u_{a^{-n}} s_{\mu}\right)^{*} s_{\nu}^{*}\left(\text { as } a^{l} \cdot \nu=\nu\right) \\
& =s_{\mu} s_{\nu} u_{a^{l} \mid_{\nu}}\left(u_{a^{-n}} \mid_{\mu}\right)^{-1} s_{\mu}^{*} s_{\nu}^{*} \\
& =s_{\mu} s_{\nu} u_{a^{l} \mid_{\nu}} u_{a^{n}} \mid_{a^{-n}} s_{\mu}^{*} s_{\nu}^{*} \\
& =s_{\mu} s_{\nu} u_{a^{l} \mid_{\nu}} u_{a^{n}} \mid_{\mu} s_{\mu}^{*} s_{\nu}^{*}\left(\text { as } a^{-n} \cdot \mu=\mu\right) \\
& =\left(s_{\nu} u_{a^{n}} s_{\nu}^{*}\right)\left(s_{\mu} u_{a^{l}} s_{\mu}^{*}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

It now follows from Lemma 4.15 that $\mathcal{F}$ is commutative.
Lemma 4.17. $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}=\overline{\operatorname{span}}\left\{s_{\mu} u_{a^{n}} s_{\nu}^{*}: \mu, \nu \in \Lambda_{\mathbb{1}}\right.$ with $\left.\mathfrak{m}^{d(\mu)}=\mathfrak{m}^{d(\nu)}, n \in \mathbb{Z}\right\}$.
Proof. Similar to [54], ${ }^{4}$ it suffices to show $x \in \operatorname{Ran} \Phi_{\mathbf{p}} \cap \mathcal{F}^{\prime}$ has the given form. By the CuntzKrieger relation, one could assume that $x=s_{\mu} A s_{\nu}^{*}$ with $d(\mu)-d(\nu)=\mathbf{p}$ and $A \in \mathrm{C}^{*}\left(u_{a}\right)$. One could further assume that $A=f\left(u_{a}\right)$, where $f(z)=\sum_{i=1}^{n} \lambda_{i} z^{M_{i}} \neq 0$ for some $0 \neq \lambda_{i} \in \mathbb{C}$ and $M_{i} \in \mathbb{Z}$.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{4}$ The details will be included in the first author's PhD thesis.

Also, it is clear that $s_{\mu} s_{\nu}=s_{\nu} s_{\mu}$ and $s_{\mu} s_{\nu}^{*}=s_{\nu}^{*} s_{\mu}$ for all $\mu, \nu \in \Lambda_{\mathbb{1}_{k}}$. Then, for all $N \in \mathbb{Z}$ and $\omega \in \Lambda_{\mathbb{1}_{k}}$, one has

$$
\begin{aligned}
& s_{\mu} A s_{\nu}^{*} s_{\omega} u_{a^{N}} s_{\omega}^{*}-s_{\omega} u_{a^{N}} s_{\omega}^{*} s_{\mu} A s_{\nu}^{*} \\
= & s_{\mu}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \lambda_{i} u_{a^{M_{i}}}\right) s_{\omega} s_{\nu}^{*} u_{a^{N}} s_{\omega}^{*}-s_{\omega} u_{a^{N}} s_{\mu} s_{\omega}^{*}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \lambda_{i} u_{a^{M_{i}}}\right) s_{\nu}^{*} \\
= & s_{\mu} s_{\omega}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \lambda_{i} u_{a^{M_{i} w^{d(\omega)}}}+u_{a^{N m^{d(\nu)}}} s_{\nu}^{*} s_{\omega}^{*}-s_{\omega} s_{\mu} u_{a^{N m^{d(\mu)}}}^{\prime}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \lambda_{i} u_{a^{M_{i} w^{d(\omega)}}}\right) s_{\omega}^{*} s_{\nu}^{*} \\
= & s_{\mu} s_{\omega}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \lambda_{i} u_{a^{M_{i} w^{d(\omega)}}}\right)\left(u_{a^{N m^{d(\nu)}}}-u_{a^{N m^{d(\mu)}}}^{\prime}\right) s_{\omega}^{*} s_{\nu}^{*} \\
= & s_{\mu} s_{\omega} f\left(u_{a^{m^{d(\omega)}}}^{\prime}\right)\left(u_{a^{N m^{d(\nu)}}}-u_{a^{N m^{d(\mu)}}}^{\prime}\right) s_{\omega}^{*} s_{\nu}^{*}
\end{aligned}
$$

After identifying $\mathrm{C}^{*}(a)$ with $\mathrm{C}(\mathbb{T})$ (see Proposition 2.7), the above is equal to 0 iff

$$
f\left(z^{\mathfrak{m}^{d(\omega)}}\right)\left(z^{N \mathfrak{m}^{d(\nu)}}-z^{N \mathfrak{m}^{d(\mu)}}\right)=0
$$

and therefore, if and only if $\mathfrak{m}^{d(\mu)}=\mathfrak{m}^{d(\nu)}$.
Lemma 4.18. $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$ is a MASA of $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda\left(\mathbb{1}_{k}, \mathfrak{m}\right)}$.
Proof. We first show that $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$ is abelian. For this, let $A:=s_{\mu} u_{a^{M}} s_{\nu}^{*}$ and $B:=s_{\alpha} u_{a^{N}} s_{\beta}^{*}$ be two standard generators in $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
& A B=s_{\mu} u_{a^{M}} s_{\nu}^{*} s_{\alpha} u_{a^{N}} s_{\beta}^{*}=s_{\mu} u_{a^{M}} s_{\alpha} s_{\nu}^{*} u_{a^{N}} s_{\beta}^{*}=s_{\mu} s_{\alpha} u_{a^{M} \mathfrak{m}^{d(\alpha)}} u_{a^{N} \mathfrak{m}^{d(\nu)}} s_{\nu}^{*} s_{\beta}^{*} \\
& B A=s_{\alpha} u_{a^{N}} s_{\beta}^{*} s_{\mu} u_{a^{M}} s_{\nu}^{*}=s_{\alpha} u_{a^{N}} s_{\mu} s_{\beta}^{*} u_{a^{M}} s_{\nu}^{*}=s_{\mu} s_{\alpha} u_{a^{N} \mathfrak{m}^{d(\mu)}} u_{a^{M} \mathfrak{m}^{d(\beta)}} s_{\nu}^{*} s_{\beta}^{*}
\end{aligned}
$$

But $\mathfrak{m}^{d(\mu)}=\mathfrak{m}^{d(\nu)}$ and $\mathfrak{m}^{d(\alpha)}=\mathfrak{m}^{d(\beta)}$ as $A, B \in \mathcal{F}^{\prime}$. Thus $A B=B A$ and so $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$ is abelian.
Now we show $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$ is a MASA. Let $s_{\alpha} u_{a^{N}} s_{\beta}^{*} \in \mathcal{F}^{\prime}$ and $s_{\mu} A s_{\nu}^{*} \in \operatorname{Ran} \Phi_{\mathfrak{p}} \cap \mathcal{F}^{\prime \prime}$ with $A \in \mathrm{C}^{*}\left(u_{a}\right)$. Similar to the proof of Lemma 4.17, we have for all $\mu, \nu \in \Lambda_{\mathbb{1}_{k}}$ and $N \in \mathbb{Z}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& s_{\mu} A s_{\nu}^{*} s_{\alpha} u_{a^{N}} s_{\beta}^{*}-s_{\alpha} u_{a^{N}} s_{\beta}^{*} s_{\mu} A s_{\nu}^{*} \\
= & s_{\mu}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \lambda_{i} u_{a^{M_{i}}}\right) s_{\alpha} s_{\nu}^{*} u_{a^{N}} s_{\beta}^{*}-s_{\alpha} u_{a^{N}} s_{\mu} s_{\beta}^{*}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \lambda_{i} u_{a^{M_{i}}}\right) s_{\nu}^{*} \\
= & s_{\mu} s_{\alpha}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \lambda_{i} u_{a^{M_{i} m^{d(\alpha)}}}+u_{a^{N m^{d(\nu)}}}^{\prime} s_{\nu}^{*} s_{\beta}^{*}-s_{\alpha} s_{\mu} u_{a^{N m^{d(\mu)}}}^{\prime}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \lambda_{i} u_{a^{M_{i} m^{d(\beta)}}}+s_{\beta}^{*} s_{\nu}^{*}\right. \\
= & s_{\alpha} s_{\mu}\left[\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \lambda_{i} u_{a^{M_{i} m^{d(\alpha)}}}+u_{a^{N m^{d(\nu)}}}^{\prime}-u_{a^{N m^{d(\mu)}}}^{\prime}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \lambda_{i} u_{a^{M_{i} m^{d(\beta)}}}+s_{\beta}^{*} s_{\nu}^{*}\right.\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

Identify $\mathrm{C}^{*}\left(u_{a}\right)$ with $\mathrm{C}(\mathbb{T})$ and notice $m^{d(\alpha)}=m^{d(\beta)}$. Then the above is equal to 0 , iff

$$
f\left(z^{\mathfrak{m}^{d(\alpha)}}\right)\left(z^{N \mathfrak{m}^{d(\nu)}}-z^{N \mathfrak{m}^{d(\mu)}}\right)=0 \Longleftrightarrow \mathfrak{m}^{d(\mu)}=\mathfrak{m}^{d(\nu)}
$$

Hence $s_{\mu} A s_{\nu}^{*} \in \mathcal{F}^{\prime}$ and therefore $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}=\mathcal{F}^{\prime \prime}$.

Now suppose that $\left\{\left|m_{i}\right|: 1 \leq i \leq k\right\}$ is multiplicatively independent. Then $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}=\mathcal{F}$, which is also the diagonal subalgebra of $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda\left(\mathbb{1}_{k}, \mathrm{~m}\right)}$. So there is a conditional expectation $\Phi$ from $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda\left(\mathbb{1}_{k}, \mathrm{~m}\right)}$ onto $\mathcal{F}$. Therefore $\mathcal{F}$ is a Cartan subalgebra of $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda\left(\mathbb{1}_{k}, \mathrm{~m}\right)}$.

Corollary 4.19. Suppose that $\left\{\left|m_{i}\right|: 1 \leq i \leq \mathrm{k}\right\}$ is multiplicatively independent. Then $\mathcal{F}$ is a Cartan subalgebra of $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda(\mathbb{1}, \mathrm{~m})}$.

Suppose that $m_{i}>0(1 \leq i \leq \mathrm{k})$. For convenience, we use the convention: If $\left.a\right|_{\mu}=a^{n}$, then $t^{\ln a_{\mu}^{\prime}}:=t^{\ln n}$. Thus

$$
\left.\ln a\right|_{\mu \nu}=\ln \mathfrak{m}^{d(\mu \nu)}=\ln \mathfrak{m}^{d(\mu)}+\left.\ln \mathfrak{m}^{d(\nu)}=\ln a\right|_{\mu}+\left.\ln a\right|_{\nu}
$$

Therefore we obtain action $\alpha$ of $\mathbb{T}$ on $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda\left(\mathbb{1}_{k}, \mathrm{~m}\right)}$ as follows:

$$
\alpha_{t}\left(s_{\mu}\right)=t^{\ln a_{\mu}^{\prime}} s_{\mu}, \alpha_{t}\left(u_{a}\right)=u_{a} \text { for all } \mu \in \Lambda_{\mathbb{1}_{k}} \text { and } t \in \mathbb{T}
$$

Define

$$
\Psi(x):=\int_{\mathbb{T}} \alpha_{t}(x) d t \quad \text { for all } \quad x \in \mathcal{O}_{\Lambda(\mathbb{1}, \mathrm{~m})}
$$

Lemma 4.20. Suppose that $m_{i}>0(1 \leq i \leq \mathrm{k})$. Then $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$ is the fixed point algebra of $\alpha$. Furthermore, $\Psi$ a faithful conditional expectation from $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda\left(\mathbb{1}_{k}, \mathrm{~m}\right)}$ onto $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$.

Proof. We only need to show the faithfulness of $\Psi$ here, as other parts can be proved similarly to the corresponding parts for $\Phi_{0}$. Let $\left.\Phi_{0}\right|_{\mathcal{F}^{\prime}}$ be the restriction of $\Phi_{0}$ onto $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$, and $\Psi$ be the expectation induced from $\alpha$ above. Then one can check that $\Phi_{0}=\left.\Phi\right|_{\mathcal{F}^{\prime}} \circ \Psi$. The faithfulness of $\Psi$ follows from that of $\Phi_{0}$.

Theorem 4.21. Suppose that $m_{i}>0(1 \leq i \leq \mathrm{k})$. Then $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$ is a Cartan subalgebra of $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda\left(\mathbb{1}_{k}, \mathrm{~m}\right)}$.

Proof. It remains to show that $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$ is regular, For this, let $A:=s_{\mu} u_{a}^{M} s_{\nu}^{*} \in \mathcal{F}^{\prime}$ and $B:=$ $s_{\alpha} u_{a}^{N} s_{\beta}^{*} \in \mathcal{O}_{\Lambda\left(\mathbb{1}_{k}, \mathrm{~m}\right)}$. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
B^{*} A B & =s_{\beta} u_{a^{-N}} s_{\alpha}^{*} s_{\mu} u_{a^{M}} s_{\nu}^{*} s_{\alpha} u_{a^{N}} s_{\beta}^{*} \\
& =s_{\beta} u_{a^{-N}} s_{\mu} s_{\alpha}^{*} u_{a^{M}} s_{\alpha} s_{\nu}^{*} u_{a^{N}} s_{\beta}^{*} \\
& =s_{\beta} s_{\mu} u_{a^{-N m}} d(\mu) u_{a^{M m}} d(\alpha) s_{\alpha}^{*} s_{\alpha} s_{\nu}^{*} u_{a^{N}} s_{\beta}^{*} \\
& =s_{\beta} s_{\mu} u_{a^{-N m}} d(\mu) u_{a^{M m}} d(\alpha) u_{a^{N m}} d(\nu) s_{\nu}^{*} s_{\beta}^{*} \\
& =s_{\beta} s_{\mu} u_{a^{M m}} d(\alpha) s_{\nu}^{*} s_{\beta}^{*}\left(\text { as } \mathfrak{m}^{d(\mu)}=\mathfrak{m}^{d(\nu)}\right) \\
& \in \mathcal{F}^{\prime}
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$ is regular.
Let $G$ be a discrete (countable) group. A subgroup $S \subseteq G$ is called immediately centralizing if, for every $g \in G$, we either have $\left\{x g x^{-1}: x \in S\right\}=\{g\}$ or $\left\{x g x^{-1}: x \in S\right\}$ is infinite. ${ }^{5}$

Theorem 4.22. $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$ is a Cartan subalgebra of $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda\left(\mathbb{1}_{k}, \mathrm{~m}\right)}$.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{5}$ This definition is slightly different from the one used in [20], but mentioned in [18] and [19]. Thanks to Anna Duwenig and Rachael Norton for some discussion.

Proof. Let $G:=\left\langle a, \mathbf{x}_{i}: a \mathbf{x}_{i}=\mathbf{x}_{i} a^{m_{i}}, 1 \leq i \leq \mathrm{k}\right\rangle$. Then it it easy to see that $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda\left(\mathbb{1}_{k}, \mathfrak{m}\right)} \cong$ $\mathrm{C}^{*}(G)$ via $u_{a} \mapsto a$ and $s_{\mathbf{x}_{i}} \mapsto \mathbf{x}_{i}$. By [40], $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda\left(\mathbb{1}_{k}, \mathfrak{m}\right)}$ is amenable and so is $\mathrm{C}^{*}(G)$. Thus $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda\left(\mathbb{1}_{k}, \mathfrak{m}\right)} \cong \mathrm{C}^{*}(G) \cong \mathrm{C}_{i}^{*}(G)$.

Let $S:=\left\{\mu a^{n} \nu^{-1}: \mathfrak{m}^{d(\mu)}=\mathfrak{m}^{d(\nu)}, n \in \mathbb{Z}\right\}$. Similar to the proof of Theorem 4.21, one can easily show that $S$ is a normal subgroup of $G$. Also, analogous to the proof of Lemma $4.18,{ }^{6}$ one can show that, for $\alpha a^{k} \beta^{-1} \in G$, if the set $\left\{\left(\mu a^{n} \nu^{-1}\right)\left(\alpha a^{k} \beta^{-1}\right)\left(\nu a^{-n} \mu^{-1}\right): \mu, \nu \in\right.$ $\Lambda\left(\mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}, \mathfrak{m}\right), n \in \mathbb{Z}\}$ is not a singleton, then it has to be infinite. Indeed,

$$
\left(\mu a^{n} \nu^{-1}\right)\left(\alpha a^{k} \beta^{-1}\right)\left(\nu a^{-n} \mu^{-1}\right)=\left(\mu^{\prime} a^{n^{\prime}} \nu^{\prime-1}\right)\left(\alpha a^{k} \beta^{-1}\right)\left(\nu^{\prime} a^{-n^{\prime}} \mu^{\prime-1}\right) \Longleftrightarrow n \mathfrak{m}^{d(\mu^{\prime})}=n^{\prime} \mathfrak{m}^{d(\mu)}
$$

Hence $S$ is immediately centralizing. By [20, Theorem 3.1], $\mathrm{C}_{i}^{*}(S)$ is Cartan in $\mathrm{C}_{i}^{*}(G)$. Therefore $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$ is Cartan in $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda\left(\mathbb{1}_{k}, \mathfrak{m}\right)}$.
Remark 4.23. Notice that, since $\Lambda_{\mathbb{1}_{k}}$ has a unique infinite path, every triple $\left(\mu, a^{n}, \nu\right)$ is cycline. So the cycline subalgebra of $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda\left(\mathbb{1}_{k}, \mathfrak{m}\right)}$ coincides with $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda\left(\mathbb{1}_{k}, \mathfrak{m}\right)}$, and does not provide much information of the canonical Cartan subalgebra $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$ in general.
4.5. The spectrum of $\mathcal{F}$. We end this paper by computing the spectrum of $\mathcal{F}$ to connect with Furstenberg's $\times p, \times q$ conjecture in the viewpoint of $[8,24]$. Let $1 \leq p_{1}, \ldots, p_{n} \in \mathbb{N}$ and

$$
\varphi: \mathbb{T} \rightarrow \mathbb{T}, z \mapsto z^{p_{1} \cdots p_{n}}
$$

Then the inverse limit

$$
\underline{\lim }_{i} \in \mathbb{T}, \varphi):=\left\{\left(x_{n}\right)_{n \in \mathbb{N}} \in \prod_{n \in \mathbb{N}} \mathbb{T}: x_{n}=\varphi\left(x_{n+1}\right) \text { for all } n \in \mathbb{N}\right\}
$$

is a solenoid, denoted as $S_{p_{1} \cdots p_{n}}$.
Let $\mathfrak{c}:=\mathbf{x}_{1} \cdots \mathbf{x}_{\mathrm{k}}$, the unique path in $\Lambda_{\mathbb{1}_{k}}$ of degree $\mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{k}}$. For $n \in \mathbb{N}$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{F}_{n \mathbb{1}_{k}} & =\overline{\operatorname{span}}\left\{s_{\mathfrak{c}^{n}} u_{a^{m}} s_{\mathfrak{c}^{n}}^{*} \mid m \in \mathbb{Z}\right\} \\
\mathcal{F} & =\overline{\operatorname{span}}\left\{s_{\mathfrak{c}^{n}} u_{a^{m}} s_{\mathfrak{c}^{n}}^{*} \mid n \in \mathbb{N}, m \in \mathbb{Z}\right\}=\overline{\bigcup_{n \in \mathbb{N}} \mathcal{F}_{n \mathbb{1}_{k}}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that for any $n \in \mathbb{N}, s_{\mathfrak{c}^{n}} u_{a} s_{\mathfrak{c}^{n}}^{*}$ is a unitary that generates $\mathcal{F}_{n \mathbb{1}_{k}}$. Then one can see that there is an isomorphism $\psi_{n}: \mathcal{F}_{n \mathbb{1}_{k}} \rightarrow \mathrm{C}(\mathbb{T})$.

Let $\mathfrak{M}:=\prod_{i=1}^{\mathrm{k}} m_{i}$.
Proposition 4.24. Consider the subalgebras $\mathcal{F}_{n \mathbb{1}_{k}}$ along with the inclusions $\varphi_{n}: \mathcal{F}_{n \mathbb{1}_{k}} \hookrightarrow$ $\mathcal{F}_{(n+1) \mathbb{1}_{k}}$ given by $\varphi_{n}\left(s_{\mathfrak{c}^{n}} u_{a^{p}} s_{\mathfrak{c}^{n}}^{*}\right)=s_{\mathfrak{c}^{n+1}} u_{a^{p m}} s_{\mathfrak{c}^{n+1}}^{*}$. Then $\mathcal{F}=\varliminf_{n \rightarrow \infty} \mathcal{F}_{n \mathbb{1}_{k}}$, and the spectrum of $\mathcal{F}$ is homeomorphic to $S_{\mathfrak{M}}$.

Proof. Notice that

$$
s_{\mathfrak{c}^{n}} u_{a^{p}} s_{\mathfrak{c}^{n}}^{*}=s_{\mathfrak{c}^{n}} s_{\mathfrak{c}} s_{\mathfrak{c}}^{*} u_{a^{p}} s_{\mathfrak{c}^{n}}^{*}=s_{\mathfrak{c}^{n+1}} u_{a^{p m}} s_{\mathfrak{c}^{n+1}}^{*}
$$

This shows that $\varphi_{n}$ is indeed an inclusion of $\mathrm{C}^{*}$-algebras. Since the union $\bigcup_{n=0}^{\infty} \mathcal{F}_{n \mathbb{1}_{k}}$ is dense in $\mathcal{F}$ (actually they are equal), we have that $\mathcal{F}$ is isomorphic to the direct limit of $\left(\mathcal{F}_{n \mathbb{1}_{k}}, \varphi_{n}\right)$ (see [43] Remark 6.1.3).

Due to [51, Theorem 2], the spectrum of $\mathcal{F}$ is the projective limit of the spectra of the subalgebras $\mathcal{F}_{n \mathbb{1}_{k}}$, with the maps $\phi_{n+1}: \widehat{\mathcal{F}_{(n+1) \mathbb{1}_{k}}} \rightarrow \widehat{\mathcal{F}_{n \mathbb{1}_{k}}}$ which induce the maps $\varphi_{n}$. However

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{6}$ Actually, it is easier here since $A=a^{n}$ for some $n \in \mathbb{Z}$.

we will work with an isomorphic direct system in order to make things more concrete. Observe that we have an isomorphism $\psi_{n}$ between $\mathcal{F}_{n \mathbb{1}_{k}}$ and $\mathrm{C}(\mathbb{T})$ that sends the element $s_{\ell^{n}} a s_{\ell^{n}}^{*} \in \mathcal{F}_{n}$ to the function $f(z)=z$ in $\mathrm{C}(\mathbb{T})$, which we will just denote by $z$ (note that $z$ is a unitary element that generates $\mathrm{C}(\mathbb{T})$ ). Let $\varphi_{n}^{\prime}: \mathrm{C}(\mathbb{T}) \rightarrow \mathrm{C}(\mathbb{T})$ be the map defined by sending the function $z$ to $z^{\mathfrak{M}}$. Then by a direct calculation the following diagram commutes:
![img-0.jpeg](img-0.jpeg)

By [51, Proposition 2], $\mathcal{F}$ is then isomorphic to the direct limit of the system $\left(\mathrm{C}(\mathbb{T}), \varphi_{n, n+1}^{\prime}\right)$. We now observe that homeomorphism $\rho: \mathbb{T} \rightarrow \mathbb{T}$ defined by $\rho(z)=z^{\mathfrak{M}}$ induces the maps $\varphi_{n}^{\prime}: \mathrm{C}(\mathbb{T}) \rightarrow \mathrm{C}(\mathbb{T})$, and so the spectrum $\mathcal{F}$ is homeomorphic to the projective limit of

$$
\mathbb{T} \stackrel{\rho}{\leftarrow} \mathbb{T} \stackrel{\rho}{\leftarrow} \mathbb{T} \stackrel{\rho}{\leftarrow} \mathbb{T} \stackrel{\rho}{\leftarrow} \ldots
$$

which is precisely $S_{\mathfrak{M}}$.
Remark 4.25. One can show that $\mathcal{O}_{\Lambda\left(\mathbb{1}_{k}, \mathfrak{m}\right)} \cong \mathcal{F} \ltimes \mathbb{Z}^{\mathrm{k}} \cong \mathrm{C}\left(S_{\mathfrak{M}}\right) \ltimes \mathbb{Z}^{\mathrm{k}}$. In fact, the action of $\mathbb{Z}^{\mathrm{k}}$ on $\mathcal{F}$ is given by

$$
\alpha: \mathbb{Z}^{\mathrm{k}} \rightarrow \operatorname{Aut} \mathcal{F}, \alpha_{\mathbf{n}}(A)=s_{\nu} A s_{\nu}^{*}
$$

where $\nu$ is the unique path in $\Lambda_{\mathbb{1}_{k}}$ of degree $\mathbf{n}$.

abstract:
In this paper, we initiate the study of higher rank Baumslag-Solitar
semigroups and their related C*-algebras. We focus on two extreme, but
interesting, classes - one is related to products of odometers and the other is
related to Furstenberg's $\times p,, \times q$ conjecture. For the former
class, whose C*-algebras are studied by H. Li and the second author, we here
characterize the factoriality of the associated von Neumann algebras and
further determine their types; for the latter, we obtain their canonical Cartan
subalgebras. In the rank 1 case, we study a more general setting which
encompasses (single-vertex) generalized Baumslag-Solitar semigroups. One of our
main tools is from self-similar higher rank graphs and their C*-algebras.
